It is very easy to move around in the company and you will always be able to find something of interest within the company.
Cons: The number of engineering projects outside of HQ seems to be low and can be taken away at any given point in time because they decided to move everything to HQ.

Title: "Not perfect, but wonderful."
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Take away everything else, and the reason to work at Google is the people. I've learned more here than I have anywhere else, and everyone I've worked with has been mutually interested in improving each other. Being able to attend engineering talks by people all over the organization (and world) is a hugely enriching experience.
Cons: Google is inevitably becoming bigger and more corporate as time goes on. Sometimes leadership will make a decision that seems only to benefit the company to the detriment of employees or users. If you step back, everything is still great overall so it's hard to complain, but it can be troubling at times. Whenever that happens I just hug my stock real tight and remember that I can always bail if things actually start …

Oh the irony that one of the most money-making units of the company is one of the least "Googley" in terms of freedom for employees and transparency of the role during interviews.

Title: "Fantastic place to work."

Title: "Energetic office environment, great colleagues, okay total compensation, diificult location"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Motivated and intelligent coworkers. Good food, snacks, and drinks. Opportunities for business travel. Internal transfer is highly supported. Engaging work and the (potential) ability to have a large impact. People generally behave predictably and professionally. Numerous company sponsored activities, groups, and classes. Shuttle system is efficient if you can handle the 2 to 4 hour round trip commute from SF.
Cons: Suburban office location is quite dull. Cost of living is *extremely* high. Total compensation is just okay considering the latter. The salary however, is just plain mediocre. You often learn about the cool things Google does after it leaks to the media, not internally. Many products and positions lack excitement and attention. The sales/partnerships side of the company will always play second fiddle to engineering …

Title: "Best place to work with exceptions"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Salary is incredible, with annual bonus and stock grant refreshes. Benefits and perks are outstanding. You won't find a total compensation package this good anywhere else. Best of all, people look at you like you're a rock star when you tell them where you work.
Cons: If you're not working in Mountain View you have very little growth opportunity. You can end up on projects that you know nothing about and have no interest in.

Title: "Good experience, but depends on which group you are in"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Everything you hear about Google is true -- free perks, lunch, dinner, dentist on-site. It feels like an idealistic utopia. Lots of super smart people, but sometimes high ego and out of touch with reality.
Cons: Unless you are a software engineer or senior exec, your pay and career advancement opportunities are limited. It's also a massive company, so your experience depends greatly on which group and manager you have.

Title: "Customer service, data base, sale, design cashier, call, lobby host"

Title: "Don't join Google's gTech org"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Great perks and benefits. Nice facilities.
Cons: gTech is a highly political org with many more layers of hierarchy than other orgs (Eng, Product, Marketing, etc.). This culture spurs unhealthy competition between co-workers who should be collaborating. It also doesn't make use of individual contributors' skill-sets, resulting in smart people doing low-level things.

Title: "A unique place to work... just not satisfying for me"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Top notch talent... I've never worked with such a collection of smart and passionate folks. Benefits are obviously among the best in the business. Tech support staff that's actually knowledgeable and responsive... stuff actually gets resolved quickly (may seem funny to harp on that but the point is... the company makes investments to make problems like this vanish)
Cons: Definitely felt like a smaller fish in a big pond... not used to that. Although they've invested mightily in developer productivity, there are still a lot of impediments. Part of why I left was I didn't have faith/passion about the product strategy I was working within (won't say why I left). Bottom line is, I'm a very PRODUCT focused engineer, not a TECHNOLOGY focused engineer... I know that may seem odd but it's …

Title: "Paradise with a few setbacks"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: There are so many people who are recognized world-wide and have their own wikipedia page that you can meet while working at this company. There is also a death benefit, which is when a Google employee passes away, their stock vests immediately, and their surviving spouse receives 50% of their salary for the next 10 years. They really do want to take care of you.
Cons: This is just the inevitable problem associated with companies that amass a large size and establishment in the market, but it's hard for employees themselves to innovate. Also, there are just too many over-qualified employees at Google who are relegated to simpler roles.

Title: "Stay aware from Consumer Operations department"

Cons: - The department you go to will dictate whether you have a great time or terrible time at Google.

Title: "Very good culture and benefits, so-so leadership and processes"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: In general, a very talented, Googley workforce - but unfortunately there are still some morons and jerks, but far fewer than other tech companies. The employees are usually very ethical, approachable, and mission-focused. The (well publicized) benefits are top notch, and the comp is at or slightly above industry average IMO. Managers are generally much higher caliber than any other Fortune 500 I've worked at. People …
Cons: There are a lot of internal inefficiencies and chaos resulting from weak leadership, flawed in-house tools, and lack of processes/controls. People are straining and working long hours just to keep the lights on, without much time and energy (and motivation) left to innovate. There are maturity and professionalism deficiencies at many levels - I especially hate the lack of ownership at times (people expecting you to …

Title: "An amazing place to work, grow, and have fun"
Main Text: Approves of CEO

Title: "Good in general"

Title: "Suffered by BigGo. decease, still a great company."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: Ambitious projects, many products actually used by millions of people, certain level of autonomy including good W/L balance, great peaks, top notch salary.
Cons: Many projects are large and hard to make impact. There are many interesting projects but it's hard to join these unless you have top-level experience to demonstrate. The bottom-up culture conflicts recent top down trend and there are confusion around the ongoing cultural change.

Title: "Interesting experience"
Main Text: However, most of the time, the management is very in tune and sought to avoid problems with employees.
Pros: I definitely enjoyed working with all the smart and motivated people in the company.
Cons: Sometimes, people seem a bit pretentious. Working with some of these people with large egos could be challenging and dosent make for the best work environment.

Title: "Amazing company and culture - Sales - be ready for dashboards, McKinsey, and metrics that matter!"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Culture, Perks, Pay (depending on role), benefits, really smart googley people
Cons: Focus on quarterly quota makes for short-term sales push that can hurt client relationships and longer-term strategy. Sales leads and Managers can go from rock-stars to borderline performer in 1-2 quarters all driven by hitting the number. The googley, we care about our people spirit is hit/miss.

Title: "Great overall working experience here."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Excellent benefits and great employee interactions.
Cons: The commute from San Francisco can be a little long but is rewarding when you get to work here.

Title: "Fast-paced work environment; smart people."
Main Text: I worked at Google (Less than a year)
Pros: A lot of the coworkers are extremely smart. You are given lots of responsibility and you have the ability to work on new and exciting products.
Cons: Although it is not formalized, many people work long hours. Also, it is easy to feel overwhelmed or even out-of-place in the office. The standards are very high.

Title: "Great projects, people, pay"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Smart bunch of people, projects that impact millions, leadership willing to take a long view that might take years to pay off, fair scope for decision making even at the bottom of the org chart. Offices, food, benefits are all icing on top. Amazing opportunities to do big things if you can make the pitch and execute on it.
Cons: Promotion process can be slow and painful; you have to be a self-starter to identify a team with opportunities for growth and be really proactive about chasing these. Working in remote offices can be difficult from a career p.o.v. depending on what projects are available. Every project I've worked on has felt somewhat Mountain View-centric, you have to adapt to that. Obamacare is dragging health benefits down …

Title: "Awesome culture"

Pros: Great team. Opportunities to work with industry experts. Awesome perks and food.
Cons: There are no cons that I can think of. It's a great place to work.

As it grows it has lots of big company bs and politics that come with that. If you think Google once you get to Google everything you hate about working in cooperate america will be better you will be very disappointed.

Title: "Love Google."

Title: "Spectacular Employer"

Title: "Great perks, but they own you and it's driving the entrepreneurial types away"
Main Text: Diversify your revenue streams, or the market will eventually smack you.
Pros: Google hires very smart people and allows them to participate in the culture. This means your coworkers will likely be very interesting and fun, and you'll probably enjoy the office environment immensely. You'll learn a lot. The hours are very flexible and the company takes the notion of work-life balance as it applies to the workday very seriously (though there's a dark reason for this). And the perks are second to …
Cons: The cons are flipped versions of the pros: Google hires very smart people and then puts them in fairly mundane roles. They used to try to take your preferences into account when allocating; they seem to do much less of this as they've grown. If you're at all purpose-driven, you'll eventually become restless at work, looking for something with more meaning than the project you're on. You could potentially 20% …

Title: "Interactive Designer"

Pros: The perks, (obviously). hmmm... thats really the only positive thing I can think of.
Cons: - Management - I personally experienced the worst management. My boss didn't know how to be a manager, and would always try and steal my work, and then take credit for it later. Super micromanager. His boss way just as bad, and the director of our department is a joke. A lot of favoritism and politics, and ego filled people who think they are entitled.

Title: "Great, supportive company culture"
Main Text: I have been working at Google part-time (Less than a year)
Pros: The obvious benefits of the office are all true. The company culture is friendly and supportive. There is low power distance with superiors.
Cons: Salary is not as competitive as similar positions in other companies. I wish HR would be a little bit more transparent in terms of career planning and position fit.

Title: "Amazing things are happening at Google."
Main Text: A luxury of an issue, I know. But there are good opportunities to switch roles and teams.
Pros: Innovative, fast moving company that refuses to stand still. Lots of great people. Extremely generous compensation and perks. Rated the best place to work (again) for a very good reason.
Cons: With so much going on at any given time, it can be difficult not to want to be a part of it all and focus on the job you're supposed to be doing.

Title: "Gsx"

Title: "Awesome!"

Title: "Good Experience"

Title: "Great place to work"

Title: "Great people"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time
Pros: I've met some of the nicest and smartest people ever at Google. The community is really amazing. Perks are unbelievable: free food, 401k and donation match, generous vacation schedule. I was able to maintain a very reasonable schedule and maintain a personal life even close to project deadlines.
Cons: You may feel only a cog in a large machines. Some projects must be done even if nobody really cares. Very limited bottom-up innovation or decisions. There are some amazing projects, really pushing the future, and some less exciting. According to your luck, you may be building robots, or plug-ins for Google Plus.

Title: "Nice work environment."
Main Text: The management is quite flat. Engineer has the freedom to choose project to work on.
Pros: Good life and work balance. Co-workers has good tech experience, you can learn a lot from them.
Cons: It's a large cooperation, so sometimes you are working on a small piece. And even a small launch will affect a lot of user, so you need to spend a lot of time working on details, to make sure you are doing correct thing.

Title: "Research Intern"

Title: "Google is an innovative company to work for"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: It is simply a privilege working with a company of such stature and influence. The professionals are bright ambitious and enthusiastic.
Cons: The corporate culture highly values 'scrappy' which frequently means that being thorough and laying down long lasting foundations are over looked in the exchange for being fast.

Title: "Amazing company with incredible people, but starting to feel too big"
Main Text: Apathy - With the size of the company, its hard to feel like each individual can make a difference. I've seen that play out by people not caring about their role or project. This is my biggest worry for Google - too much apathy.
Pros: People - passionate, dedicated and want to do the best they can for Google, the world and our users.
Cons: Big - Google is a big company now. Red tape abounds and causes frustration and slow work.

Title: "Good company, getting too big and far too competitive"

Cons: Getting too big and bureaucratic, and hence very difficult to have real impact. Most VPs have been around for ~10yrs, so basically churning old leadership without too much new blood - and the old guard are not open to hearing new views, and usually surround themselves with like minded folks. Teams (my experience has been in sales ops and support..gTech internally) are "non-Googley" i.e. reward results vs how these …

Title: "Google"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: Best place to work. They have so many benefits, allow you to work 20% of time on your own projects, can bring dog to work, food court, exercise so much to love.
Cons: Sometimes I feel like I am required to live at work. I would like to spend more time with my family than is sometimes expected of me.

Title: "Best co-workers ever."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 8 years)
Pros: While the pay is good, perks are great, etc, far and away the best thing about working at Google is being able to take advantage of the font of knowledge available in your co-workers. People are genuinely helpful, with some astoundingly well-known names regularly chiming in to answer random questions on various internal mailing lists.
Cons: Company has become absolutely huge compared to what it once was and the amount of project churn definitely takes its toll. Hiring is a complete crap-shoot; offers might as well be extended via a pseudo-random number generator.

Title: "Hard work is rewarded with raises and bonuses"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Whenever I've worked extra hard or stood out, I've been rewarded with salary bumps and big bonuses. I like that my accomplishments are noticed by my manager and peers and rewarded accordingly.
Cons: Google is a big company; you need to make sure you're on the right team. I felt suffocated on my first team but LOVE my second (current) team. Some of my friends have had very different experiences because they're on different teams.

Title: "Intern for one semester at Google"
Pros: Great food and coworkers! Loved the work environment.
Cons: Not many complaints. More job opportunities at this location would be great.

Title: "There's a reason Google is always #1..."
Main Text: Show More
Pros: The benefits are unparalleled, compensation is extremely generous, a lot of opportunity if you're in the right place. Work/life balance is great (at least it is outside of Mountain View), and really dependent on the employee. Once you start working here, it is very easy to see why Google is always topping lists. Bad reviews are likely a result of someone who has never worked outside of the tech industry-they really …
Cons: The organization is too flat, considering how fast Google has grown in the last 5 years. Some groups did not promote accordingly and therefore have notable gaps in senior management. Also, I've observed some inconsistent hiring practices over the last year, with my group's upper management hiring people into senior positions that are very inexperienced. It causes a lot more work for the rest of the team, because …

Title: "Most stressful job ever. You get fired if you even sneeze too loud."
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: The Pay was great, when you got hours.
Cons: No Union, no sense of security, horrible working conditions, your not allowed to have a voice. No one seems to know what's going on, rules change every week. There are non stop emails and sometimes even phone calls during your personal time. Even after a 10 hour shift you only get 30 minutes lunch. You often have to perform the role of 3 people at once.

Title: "Great benefits and perks, but slow career growth"

Pros: Google does value its employees and offers great benefits and perks. People are considerate and respectful. Offices have nice decor and give you the feeling of a college campus.
Cons: It's a big company, and as with all big companies, there is politics. Career growth is slower than smaller companies.

Title: "Great place to work and have an impact"
Main Text: The transition to Larry Page as CEO was rocky, but I think we've come out ok, and employees are generally coming to trust Larry's leadership. Few regret Vic Gundotra's departure.
Pros: You can make a really big impact on the world working at google. There's an amazing diversity of projects, the resources available to the company are basically unequaled, and leadership is genuinely trying to do things that make the world a better place.
Cons: Google is severely lacking in gender, racial, and age diversity. It can also be easy to let Google consume your life out of work (i.e. social life); for some, though, that may not be a con.

Title: "Amazing company, beware of cult-culture"

Cons: Because the perks are so good, you don't realize how much of your life becomes defined by your job. Especially for those who start at Google early in their careers. Best advice would be to ensure you have a lot of life outside of work that are in "Google-free" zones.

Title: "It's what you make of it"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: - Working with smart, effective people: The average intelligence level here is considerably higher than anyplace else I've worked, and the people tend to be very diligent. When I need assistance from another engineer or another team, I typically get quick and effective help. Office politics exist, but compared to anywhere else I've worked they're not a problem.
Cons: - Impostor syndrome: The flip side of working with so many smart and effective people is that it can be difficult to recognize your own value; if you're used to being the smartest guy in the room and suddenly you're surrounded by people who are at or above your ability, that can be a bit of a blow to the ego. I eventually worked through this, but it took the better part of a year.

Title: "It's the best company I've ever worked for in the 38 years since I graduated college."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Very smart people, outstanding benefits and perks, excellent salaries, and lots of opportunity to do what you love. Everything you've heard about working for Google is true.
Cons: It's starting to become a little less firm in its moral stances and starting to bend with the prevailing political winds a little too much. In other words, it's starting to behave more like a multi-billion dollar international corporation than a passionate silicon valley technological trail breaker.

Title: "The People Make this Place Great!"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Incredible company full of smart, motivated employees. I've rarely encountered disgruntled employees grumbling to each other at the water cooler. Everyone is passionate about their personal hobbies and brings their A game to work every day.
Cons: It's a flat organization, which means it's difficult to get promoted or get a fancy title.

Title: "One of the best large companies to work for"
Main Text: Too large. Hard to get noticed unless you are a rockstar.
Pros: Choice and quality of work.
Cons: You compete against the best. So harder to grow.

Title: "Summer"
Pros: Google interns get paid more than most full-time employees across the country. According to Glassdoor, the average Google intern makes $5,678 per month, or $68,136 per year.
Cons: Any , perhaps to earn less than in a big investment bank but not every one car become a trader or a banker

Pros: Brilliant people.
Cons: None, if you work hard consistently. Problems only occur when you're not.

Title: "Marketing a new product at Google"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Amazing perks, seriously. I forgot my wallet at home for an entire week and never noticed until the weekend. Everything is onsite at Google. Challenging work environment where you can learn an insane amount and interact with extremely bright individuals. Having Google on your resume opens A LOT of doors.
Cons: Wildly disorganized to the point where your team, product + general efficiency suffers.So you remain frustrated. HR treats employees extremely poorly. Very difficult to get promoted. Absolutely no work-life balance whatsoever. I thought this was the dream, but was very disappointed in my experience at Google.

Title: "Great work environment"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: The perks - plenty of food, massages, shuttle, library, gifts, etc. Extremely smart co-workers to learn from. Lots of teams working on diverse projects, so you can switch things up every so often. CEO and leadership has grand visions for the future of the company.
Cons: While the salary looks high, it actually isnt so great once you factor in taxes and housing prices of the Bay Area.

Title: "good, but not for everyone"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: young, smart, creative, energetic people. i felt very supported by my manager and was encouraged to find tasks that i could excel at. however, it is important to note that not every manager is like that and some groups had very difficult and close-minded management styles.
Cons: benefits lead to a lot of entitlement among Google employees. not only does this have an impact on workplace expectations and dynamics, it also affects the larger communities within which Google employees operate. also it is important to remember that as much "good" as Google does, it is a for profit company that makes its revenue selling ads. it might be worth billions now, but that continues to be its bottom line.

Title: "Act on Employee Feedback - People managers w/ approval ratings ess than 50% YoY should not manage"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: 1) Food: Great food options. The chicken taste bland 50% of the time but it's free food. Micro Kitchen always well stocked.
Cons: 1) Org Changes: 'How Google Works,' by Eric Schmidt and Jonathan Rosenberg does not reflect Google reality. Reorgs take 6+ month and no decision gets made. Resulting in people being idle. Not every manager supports 20% projects.

Title: "Very challenging yet rewarding experience thus far"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)

Title: "Great people, great values"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: The benefits and care of employees is obviously world class, and compensation is almost unmatchable. But the company attracts some of the best talent and best people to work with in the world, which is the most important bit. Potential impact is always huge, and it's great to wake up in the morning and hear that the company you work for is going to try and defeat death, or bring internet in balloons to rural areas.
Cons: Google has gotten really large, and depending on where you are in the company, some bureaucracy and politics can get in the way. The company is very conscious of it, though, so it's less than you might see at other companies of this size. Launching is also the main emphasis -- it's hard to hire some of the brightest people in the world and ask them to just maintain some code base. Almost everyone is very …

Title: "Not the best company to work for despite the reports"

Title: "Negotiate your starting salary"

Cons: Time was always a problem. The clocks never worked.

Title: "Great place to work"
Pros: benefits, food, terrific co workers
Cons: crowded, competing for talent, remote offices

Title: "Wild place to work"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Great autonomy, lots of action, rewarding overall experience
Cons: Inconsistent, sometimes poor personnel policies. Lots of hiring hiccups. Not a company designed for people over 35. Many current employees will give Google 5 stars, but note: when it's good, it's very good, but when it's bad, it's incomprehensibly bad.

Title: "Too much hype"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Smart people, amazing company vision and ambition, perks.
Cons: Amateur management. Beyond the point of being disrespectful at times. I've seen this from the top leadership time and again. Eventually I had to leave because of a conflict with personal values. Funny thing is, those at the top were simply there first/ longest, and they are generally less competent than many of the most junior employees. Heavy bureaucracy. Kinda ridiculous to see how tactical management can get (I …

Title: "Competitive Machine of Silicon Valley"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Google presents an idyllic exterior setting: volleyball courts, free meals, and the athletic intramurals of a college campus. It has attracted many very smart people and offers good salaries. It is a technology focused company, and has produced four world changing products: Google Search, Ads, Maps, and YouTube.
Cons: Google is beset by internal competition -- the atmosphere of constant review pushes people to primp their resumes and do things to look better and make their competition look worse. Unscrupulous, loud people are rewarded, while ineffective people are treated similarly to those that actually do great work. The company is full of managers who don't really know how to manage.

Title: "Awesome company"
Pros: Culture is great so are people
Cons: No cons or negatives at all

Title: "Getting Too Big"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Great mission - creates large impact and affects people's lives. Always pushing innovation with high risks projects like self driving car and Google Glass. Googlers are compensated very well and there are lots of perks.
Cons: This may not apply to the entire company because my experience was in the Human Resources department. It has become bureaucratic and very political. Maybe this is part of being a 50,000+ company. There's too much red tape that slows down the ability to get things done. Also, success is becoming dependent on who you know and how much you sell yourself. It's no longer about your accomplishment or abilities. Title and …

Title: "Talented, driven and passionate team environment."
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: You get to focus on what you do best. Google tries its best to take care of everything else (within reason) so that you can focus on doing what you do best. Little things like: food, transportation, entertainment, and the right tools for the job ( computers, phones, and even desks)
Cons: Since it's becoming bigger and bigger, you get the feeling that you're contributions are not making a big impact. Which leads many googlers to leave after 18 months.

Title: "Really Amazing benefits"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Great benefits. Also great atmosphere. Make you feel young!
Cons: Very free, and some become not productive.

Title: "Awesome Company"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Great working culture. Very engineer-driven company. You feel that you can do what you like and are appreciated for it. Not to mention the great perks (that can get very distracting).
Cons: Everyone is super-smart and constantly tries to prove it, which can be very tiring Once you scratch the surface you realise that there are too many projects and not enough people to do them.

Title: "Great Experience"
Main Text: No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great company with great pay, benefits, and atmosphere.
Cons: At many times wanted a more rigid environment.

Title: "Great people, work, and environment"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: The company is extremely transparent internally, supports lifelong learning (if there is something you want to learn it is likely there is a class available on the topic), and you work with some of the smartest people around. The work environment is great, as is the food, fitness centers, and other added benefits.
Cons: If you end up on a project you aren't all that interested in or a team you don't quite mesh with, you may not enjoy your work as much as you could if you were placed on another team/project, though it seems fairly painless to switch teams if you aren't enjoying what you do anymore.

Title: "Great, once you learn to work smarter"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Perks, benefits, pay, work-from-home policy, and really smart people. You don't run into morons here, and that makes life *so* *much* *better*. The tools available inside are better than anything that anyone can buy, and really have no equal.
Cons: Some managers are great technically, but have no people skills whatsoever. Also, the level of work and output by your peers is very high. You have to learn to work smart to make your work-life balance fit. This means learning how to effectively use the tools (which takes time, but they're really good), to build discipline to avoid spacing out on random websites, and actively managing your time. You also have company …

Title: "Great place to be, but a hard place to work"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: The benefits are some of the best in the valley. Swimming pool, commuting bus, great free food, and the list goes on and on. Look at the dictionary for the definition of great company benefits and you will see a google logo.
Cons: Work, work, work, work, work, work and more work. Life there is tough, don't let the benefits suck you in, because behind the fatherly support, is a more ulterior motive to keep you there long, long hours by taking care of you so well. Work / life balance is tough. If your young with no life outside of work, this is a dream come true. With a family of young kids, think before you jump ... but there are worse things …

Title: "Not too shabby"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Awesome company to work for especially as your first job, Exceptional people, amazing offices, and very creative environment
Cons: Not much change in pay until a very long time . Pay is good but stagnant

Title: "Diverse & interesting people, big challenges, effective leadership, great perks"
Pros: people are great. you have the most interesting conversations with your colleagues who have super diverse interests. work quality and culture is pretty good.
Cons: nature of work is more rote than it used to be (what with the onset of "big company culture"). harder and harder to be heard over the sea of voices despite (or perhaps because of) open culture.

Title: "It's Google"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Smart people. Good engineering practices. Free food onsite three times a day is an essential convenience factor. Lots of opportunities for travel. Interesting projects. Compensation and benefits very generous. Lots of cool perks, fun offsites etc.
Cons: Capricious high-level management direction, some projects don't make sense. Working across many time zones in distributed offices is challenging at times.

Title: "Smartest people ever"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: The people are amazing, everyone is super talented and smart. Food & other perks are generous. For a large company, has a superbly impressive culture and responsiveness to employees' desires.
Cons: Individual team/group culture varies widely, some are a lot more "fun" to work on than others.

Title: "Overworked and underpaid..."
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: saying you 'work for Google', free food all day long, free shuttle transportation, lavish parties (depending on your group's visibility and corresponding budget), flexible work schedules
Cons: poor work-life balance for higher-level employees. if you are a higher-level hire with a masters degree you will find a high level of expectation from you starting on day 1, disorganized on-boarding training programs for new hires leaving you to sink or swim and figure things out on your own,

Title: "It was ok the project was great but how it was ran wasn't"
Pros: The benefit of the actual project for customers it was very helpful
Cons: The way the operation was ran was by far the worse

Title: "A Challenging and Exciting Time!"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Having a voice with upper management.
Cons: None that I can think of off the top of my head.

Title: "Hard work, but worth it."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: One of the best companies in the world to work for.
Cons: If you want work-life balance, you have to be the one to take the initiative. It won't just be handed to you.

Title: "Robotic Recruiting where all they care for is a number not quality. Shady practices to get candidates through."
Main Text: - Google Recruiting culture is different from the company.
Pros: Benefits.
Cons: -Big company, Political environment.

Title: "Software Engineer"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Best Engineering culture i have seen. The impact is very big as products scale to millions of users.
Cons: It is becoming very big and the perks are slowly falling off. This also makes it go slower than previously

Title: "A good place to start your career, but maybe not the best place to grow it fast"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: For the most part, co-workers are smart, caring and considerate people. Google also offers awesome perks and really does try to treat its employees well.
Cons: It's a really big company, and suffers some inevitable big company problems like politics and internal mobility an be more difficult than one would imagine.

Title: "Love it here."
Main Text: No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great teams and great people
Cons: It is extremely competitive here.

Title: "Limited career opportunities, in the traditional sense"
Main Text: People skew younger, which can be a drag on getting things done because 90% of people seem to be on the wrong end of a generic working life learning curve (rather than actually learning about new products and figuring out how to sell them).
Pros: Breaking new ground all the time. Lots of mental space and collaborative colleagues who are at the ready to share ideas, listen to yours, and offer connections to get them (the ideas) tested.
Cons: Promotion seems to be a question of meeting the official company roles and responsibilities for each level, rather than contribution to the bottomline.

Title: "Amazing experience, sometimes a little stifling"
Pros: Google treats its employees just amazingly well. The perks are great, the pay is very good, the work is interesting, the atmosphere is not crazy stressful.
Cons: It's become a big company. It's one of the best, if not the best, big company in the world, and I still love Google. But if you're ambitious and really want to be in the ground floor of exciting new projects, Google isn't always the easiest place to do that.

Title: "Good."
Pros: office is great, I love it!
Cons: Pretty big company and hard to learn what everyone else is doing

Title: "Great place to work!"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Freebies and free food. Decent Salary
Cons: Contractors get paid more than FTEs

Title: "Great stable job, not for entrepreneurial types"
Main Text: not much people interaction
Pros: good perks
Cons: mundane work

Title: "Great company"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Amazing mobility - there is no company that has a leading presence in as many different areas of technology. Employees are able to switch roles and teams easily, it's like being able to get a new job without leaving the nest.
Cons: Big company issues - hard to grow scope and have an individual impact.

Title: "Best company ever created in human history"
Main Text: Too many Directors (compared to T7s), many incompetent ones, very difficult to move up in some part of the company, which serves as a reason why competent people leave.
Pros: Strong vision, execution, best pay / perks, seriously aiming to make the world a better place.
Cons: Internal competition, more top down these days than before, but still better than any other company outside.

Title: "Desperately trying to stay relevant"
Main Text: Most managers actively sabotage your efforts at working on a 20% project -- very frustrating.
Pros: Looks good on your resume
Cons: Disorganized management

Title: "Amazing place!"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: I love the free food, the amazing people, and spectacular environment. A beautiful company.
Cons: It can sometimes be a little stressful, because there's a lot to be done. Hours can be long.

Title: "My experience at google was nothing short of amazing"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: So many highlights including: intelligent people, expansive budgets to accomplish your department initiatives, great perks and an amazing work environment overall. Everyone is highly driven and ambitious and when I came into work every day, I literally felt that energy as soon as I walked in through the door. People who excel in this company are self-starters and creative people that are able to think quickly and …
Cons: upward mobility is stagnant. perks can make most complacent and satisfied with their role level for years with no title promotions.

Title: "Amazing."
Pros: So many perks for employees! You have good food, many fun opportunities, good work amenities. I would say working at Google is an amazing experience.
Cons: Sometimes, hard to get a promotion. The work itself can be very challenging, and at times, colleagues may not be willing to help get you through tough codes or working experiences.

Title: "Enjoyable"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Experience in one of the largest and well know companies in the world in a great location and amongst similar minded people
Cons: the cost of living in the bay area and the long working hours make it tough to continue motivation and standards

Title: "Great company, limited opportunities in a remote office."
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Lots of learning opportunities. Fun congenial environment. Smart, motivated colleagues.
Cons: Felt pigeonholed in my roll.

Title: "Great work, hard work"
Main Text: I have been working at Google part-time (More than a year)
Pros: Excellent organization, pay, FREE coffee
Cons: Little leadership. Hours can be long, but hey, that's life.

Title: "Pretty challenging"
Main Text: low sallaries.

Title: "Lots of smart people selling ads"
Main Text: Many, many layers of management.
Pros: Perks that everyone knows about.
Cons: The work itself can be lame in many areas of the company.

Title: "Good company but hard to move up after a certain level."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 8 years)
Pros: Perks and salary are very good.
Cons: Growth stagnates after certain level.

Title: "Amazing place, strong culture but not perfect for mid / senior level managers"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Incredible culture; great transparency and excellent communication between senior management and the rest of the company. Very smart, motivated and fun people to work with. Incredibly fast paced and forward thinking company. Generally, very good products which are constantly improved on. Google is very consumer centric and also fast to learn and improve its products.
Cons: Google can be extremely competitive and is unrelenting in its pace. More importantly, for senior or mid level management you can hit a glass ceiling. The company is very product / eng driven which can at times be frustrating for sales & marketing people. Google is not organized structurally for employees looking for GM or P&L experience. It's too functionally structured for that. If you want to eventually …

Title: "Great place to work"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Best work environment for the first employment
Cons: I just can not find one con for this job

Title: "Awesome!"
Pros: It's a great place to work!
Cons: Can't think of any cons!

Title: "Everything you would expect"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: The perks, salary, stock options are extremely competitive. You also get to work with very smart coworkers.
Cons: There aren't really any cons, It's just hard to advance if your not in a top project team.

Title: "Intense environment of hyper-competitive "A" players"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: It is an amazing place to challenge yourself. There are lots of perks, but at least from my experience you are going to work very hard to keep them.
Cons: You haven't seen politics like this Neverland before. Rich people that got in early, or industry professionals who have had too much reality to adapt is the norm. Ivy League MBAs are a dime a dozen. Egos are huge, and sometimes warranted. You will feel small time, and like an idiot for a long while after you start.

Title: "Executive sales"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Fun fast past invornment. Good challenging work.
Cons: People in the office were a little snooty tooty or stuck up.

Title: "A Unique Company"
Main Text: It can sometimes feel chaotic, as if managers can't decide what they want. That's because the culture of the company is "try things and see what works." It is a good company if you thrive on uncertainty and autonomy; it is less good if you are looking for clear, consistent directions.
Pros: You get to work on problems that have incredible scale, reach, and impact.
Cons: The bottom-up culture is not for everybody.

Title: "Simple"
Pros: good food good people good benefits
Cons: not a lot of growth and minimum pay

Title: "TPM"
Main Text: - No work life balance
Pros: - Free Food
Cons: - Management

Title: "A company that demonstrates that it values the employees"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Great compensation and benefits, fantastic food and snacks, which really boost morale. A culture of respect, and opportunity to work on interesting things, and interact with many different people. Good opportunities to travel to other Google offices. As much opportunity for professional and personal growth as one would like to have.
Cons: It's a big place, spread out across many locations. Though it's a positive when it comes to travel, it can be a little challenge for getting to know others and to be known yourself.

Title: "Still the best place to work for, despite the cons"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Best people around; Cool tech, cool people, many opportunities to work with cool things.
Cons: Management sucks, and the company direction is heading south. They're focused on competitors that aren't real, and on the wrong forms of public opinion.

Title: "Great place to be a SWE"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: Amazing coworkers and collaborative culture, interesting and difficult problems, world class infrastructure that makes solving them easier. Many learning and career development opportunities.
Cons: Worst part is the interview process, but once you get past that there's very little to complain about. There's a bit of bureaucracy associated with larger companies, but not nearly as bad as at other places of similar size.

Title: "Best Large Corp to work for"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Perks, free lunches, etc. Google setup the current model for a lot of younger companies around the world and successfully created a culture of sharing and community.
Cons: Google will let you balance your life, but unless you're really good, expectations are high and a lot of overtime will be needed to reach up the ladder. Google won't force you, but it is still a meritocracy.

Title: "In and out place but still better than most places, and you learn a ton."
Main Text: I worked at Google part-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Sense of community, nice work and life balance, and grand thinking.
Cons: Getting stuck in the middle of bad management really turns your work life upside down.

Title: "Mentally challenging"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Networking, advancing the stat of art consumer technologies
Cons: work-life balance issues, high living expenses

Title: "Nice working place"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Good work-life balance and opportunity for personal growth and good compensation
Cons: Sometimes the management is well structured.

Title: "Okay"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Benefits and perks - great place to learn new things
Cons: Keeping up with the ever changing world of google

Title: "Software Engineer"
Pros: Best perks, smart teammate, nice work, environment, good, food
Cons: moving slow growing into a big company

Title: "Google is amazing"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: Great perks, great comp, great benefits, and great people! what's not to love - not to mention a great brand that makes you more valuable once it's on your resume!
Cons: WLB can be tough, sometimes. They give you a lot of leeway and expect a lot in return. Creating the future has a price, you know.

Title: "Lots of cash allow the company to invest in its people"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Great innovations, work for a company that is doing something most other companies can only imagine. Incredible benefits.
Cons: Not much in terms of team. Each person out for themselves.

Title: "Amazing place to work"
Main Text: - As the company grows, everyone starts to feel a little more anonymous
Pros: - Work on meaningful projects with incredibly smart people
Cons: - The company is getting larger, and can be harder to navigate

Title: "Best company I've ever worked for, including my own company"
Main Text: Work life balance is great.
Pros: The engineers here are the best I've ever worked with, hands down.
Cons: No real cons come to mind.

Title: "Great"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Good Benefits. Very Smart People and alot to learn from.
Cons: Hard to make a difference.

Title: "Great place to work"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Smart co workers, lots of perks, solid reliable infrastructure, great work life balance and continuing education. You learn a lot of best practices. The researchers are world class and you get to work on the bleeding edge of technology
Cons: Too large one can get lost in the megaplex. At higher levels it can get more and more political. Not much use of open source infrastructure beyond Linux

Title: "Best job ever!"
Pros: Everything has been amazing so far. I feel like I've died and gone to job heaven!
Cons: I don't have any cons right now. Maybe that it's a bit hard to understand career paths but that's super minor

Title: "Great workplace, inspires you to come to work everyday"
Main Text: There is a strong focus on operating efficiency which is good, but it does tend to clash with the free-flowing culture of the company.
Pros: Cutting edge technology, best-in-class colleagues, working with industry leaders.
Cons: Everybody is smart, so it does get very competitive. Promotions get unduly given to folks at times.

Title: "One of the best to work for!"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: Fantastic and super smart co-workers, great culture, perks and compensation package. Generous to new parents. Work hard play hard. Leadership committed to a long term growth of the company.
Cons: Company is now big which means more processes.

Title: "I really enjoy the environment"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: So much lax. freedom. Lots of fun
Cons: Job can get a little redundant

Title: "Great place to work!"
Main Text: *Amazing perks
Pros: *Smart and hardworking co-workers
Cons: Everyone I've worked with is incredibly smart (and nice). I don't view this as a con but if you are used to being the big fish in a small pond it might be an adjustment.

Title: "Challenging, Friendly, and overall rewarding"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 8 years)
Pros: The atmosphere is very helpful and kind! I remember I was Software Intern starting out in this new company. From day one, even the work was challenging but it soon payed off (literally)! Google also pays a well over average amount and they also have perks like gyms and the never ending food!
Cons: Well I can't say much but when you start out it may be very nerve racking but with the help you get you can feel right in the community!

Title: "Great culture and company"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Google was a great place to work. Aside from the amazing food! the people are smart, the offices are amazing and its just an exciting place to be.
Cons: The review process, at least when I was there, was very time-consuming and after a while it seemed to lose meaning,

Title: "Good place to work"
Main Text: Very encouraging managers
Pros: Very smart colleagues
Cons: No clear guidance on career progression

Title: "Awesome"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: The perks, really smart people, and great company culture
Cons: Big company so scope of responsibility is not as big

Title: "Wonderful Place"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Benefits, perks, interesting projects, learning and growth opportunity. Google offers a lot of career development, and even a lot of entertainment onsite.
Cons: Overheads of checking in codes, politics in certain groups. Sometimes people are spending a lot of time working just on trivial stuff.

Title: "Inspiring, supportive, challenging, rewarding."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Outstanding perks and rewards, high expectations, challenging work, lots of empowerment and minimal micromanagement, good collaboration, good lateral and vertical mobility, smart and do-the-right-thing colleagues, fair and unbiased feedback and performance evaluations, very transparent and good access to leadership.
Cons: Even the best big companies have some amount of politics and some amount of duplicate or discarded work. Plus, when you've got a lot of people working on something, the work is sharded into smaller and more specialized bits, and some of those are naturally less interesting than others.

Title: "Great experience but limited mobility"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Enjoyed access to lots of resources and smart people. Really liked the author talks from interesting writers. Free food and benefits were awesome. Explaining to people at weddings that you work for Google alleviates all further discussion of details about what you do
Cons: Hard to feel like you make an impact; convoluted career advancement procedures (need to always be strategizing around leveling up). Since the company is so big, you have to make a concerted effort to grow your skill set outside of your immediate world.

Title: "Solid at best"
Pros: Great Benifiets, great pay, good people
Cons: Hard work, stressful situations with management.

Title: "Great place to build your career"
Main Text: - Be more marketing led, rather than product led
Pros: - A lot of mobility available - career shifts to sales, marketing, etc are possible
Cons: - You can feel that it's a really big company now - difficult to advance & a lot of red tape

Title: "Good, Needs Help"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: The interesting projects and people are a huge pro for me. The salary is extremely good as well. I'm very excited to see the Company's future.
Cons: Work/Life Balance is extremely hard. I don't know why they insist on turning us into slaves. If you have a bad manager, your experience will surely be ruined.

Title: "Still good pay, still a good place to work"
Main Text: That pretty much covers it. And here are a few more words so that glassdoor will let me submit.
Pros: Pay
Cons: Not quite as exciting as some other companies. Food isn't as good as it used to be. You might be exposed to the tiniest bit of politics if you make it high enough. Nothing but first world problems.

Title: "Highly recommend to others"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Nice compensation, nice culture, career growth, nice and smart people, free food
Cons: Busier than most big companies, which is both good and bad

Title: "Positive and challenging."
Main Text: * Never a dull moment.
Pros: * Open bottom-up culture.
Cons: * Lots of competition from all the very smart coworkers. Promotions are challenging.

Title: "The best working environment in the world"
Pros: Free food nice people very good pay
Cons: There is no con about google its amazing

Title: "I really enjoyed it!"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: You work around amazing people that are passionate about what they do. You are provided with the tools that you need to get your job done and then expected to go out and produce. The benefits/perks are also great.
Cons: Sometimes the environment is too nice. As changes cascade down from top management mid level management does not speak up and question or say no. This is not different from other companies, but with the culture there you would not expect it to happen so often.

Title: "Software Engineer at Google"
Main Text: People tend to have strong opinions.
Pros: The benefits are wonderful, the people are great.
Cons: Expectations are high, and processes can get in the way.

Title: "Nowhere like it... but you have to walk on water to climb beyond Snr. Manager."
Main Text: Regional offices are not quite like Mountain View.
Pros: Embraces innovation. Singularly focused on the end user. Go big or go home.
Cons: Influx of consulting arrogance at the senior levels. Competitive.

Title: "Fantastic place to learn, grow, and work"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: Google takes care of its people. On the sales side, I enjoy a fantastic work/life balance and really love the work that I'm doing in programmatic ad sales. Vacation time is fair, pay is fair, and the perks are insane.
Cons: If you get stuck with a bad manager, it can really ruin your experience a bit. Need to know how to navigate the corporate structure in order to be successful.

Title: "Awesome company to work for"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: salary, stocks, work life balance, management, peers, it is a dream to work here everyday!
Cons: Promotions are very hard to get

Title: "The best employer I've ever had"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Everyone without exception is very good at their job. The work is interesting and varied, the perks and compensation are great, and there's very little of the normal corporate BS that tends to distract people from their job at other companies.
Cons: Because the bar is so high and the pool is so talented, it seems that sometimes people would would excel at other companies have a hard time keeping up here.

Title: "Huge but incredible"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: Despite it's size, Google continues to innovate, treat it's employees well, and have tough problems to solve. You can't go wrong by getting a job here. There are so many teams that if you don't find the perfect fit at first, just keep looking (which is easy!) and you'll probably find something to enjoy.
Cons: You won't work at the speed of a startup, even if you join a small team.

Title: "I love GOOGLE!"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Everything! I only worked here for some time but I found that the employees were great and I really liked my boss :) :) :)
Cons: None :) The culture was decent and the pay was great. I really liked this company and I am trying to work for them again it was awesome.

Title: "Google underpays when it comes to staffing and recruiting. They are way below the market. There is no work life balance."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Free food and snacks.
Cons: Very corporate now. The company is hierarchical and there is little to no access to management at the top. Long hours and no work life balance.

Title: "Great employer, smart people, with some shortcoming of being a big company"
Main Text: There are clearly hierarchy, and most of time it doesn't equate bureaucracy but sometimes it does .
Pros: Can't beat Google's culture and perks.
Cons: Company is getting big, and not everyone is moving as fast as we were before.

Title: "Bad Time to be in the Sales Org"
Main Text: Make HR less evil.
Pros: The benefits and perks of working at Google are outstanding. As a whole, I think the company does care about its employees, at the highest levels.
Cons: The sales org is a big bureaucratic mess.

Title: "Awesome company"
Main Text: Changing the world in many dimensions, across industries and always looking for new opportunities
Pros: Great place to work
Cons: Low attention span means that projects change a lot, but that also means faster innovation so its a double edged sword

Title: "Great company, awesome co workers, but getting really really big."
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Very smart management in almost every department with clear, ambitious vision. Most people at the company are self starters and have a desire to improve whether its making the products, workplace services, or even things like food and transportation for employees.
Cons: Company is getting huge, hard to navigate organization. I still believe its one of the best run large companies but at some point an organization will just get too large and loses the agility and speed that it had before.

Title: "softare engineer"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: salary si good, and you can catch up with latest tech.
Cons: work longer time than normal company

Title: "Fantastic company"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: The rumors about the glamorous work environment at Google are true. You're in a comfortable workplace surrounded by the best people and practically smothered with perks.
Cons: The fabulous perks are there to keep the highly skilled employees complacent while they perform the menial, repetitive, labor that is required to keep the machine running. On any given eventing, many a Googler can be heard lamenting his/her under-stimulating project at any given Palo Alto watering hole.

Title: "Very high caliber of talent. Fast-paced work environment"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: Amazing perks, flexibility of hours and work/life balance. Laidback and collaborative work culture. Great opportunities for classes and personal development
Cons: Difficult to move up and take on more challenging roles. Not a great place to begin a career outside of engineering

Title: "Yes, it really is a great place to work!"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 8 years)
Pros: Fantastic benefits. A culture that motivates a strong work ethic. Access to some of the worlds best leaders in areas of machine learning and large scale data algorithms.
Cons: Not as much freedom to innovate as one might expect. The quarterly review cycle tends to throw out the idea of trying for a longer term vision.

Title: "Awesome, except I was on contract."
Main Text: No opinion of CEO
Pros: campus perks and the people are really awesome
Cons: communication is all over the place

Title: "Amazing company!!!"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: I have something to compare with. This is the place where you can spend life working on interesting problems, and picking the team where you want to work.
Cons: None. I mean it. It is a corporation now, but still most of the things are very very reasonable

Title: "Awesome company, awful experience"
Main Text: - Study the job satisfaction of Googlers in technical roles that fall under and are managed by non-technical Googlers (e.g. in Sales).
Pros: Awesome company, amazing founders and senior management, and ofcourse, great perks. You feel a sense of pride, accomplishment and excitement walking into work every morning.
Cons: While company is great, your particular team and work experience could be awful. You could work really really long hours and pick up the slack for the rest of the team. Many managers hire accomplished and seasoned staff, primarily, to make up for their own lack of experience and knowledge. So you may find yourself without proper guidance, and in the position of a workhorse. This company is best for people who join …

Title: "Great"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: Good culture. Wacky HQ. Good Perks
Cons: Bad management, some leaders take things not so seriously

Title: "Great perks, but proceed with caution when choosing a role."
Main Text: Show More
Pros: The perks are amazing, food, gym membership, transportation, massages, trainings all provided. If you're savvy enough you can find your way into working on some pretty cool things.
Cons: Too many people doing jobs they're overqualified for. This leads to increased employee dissatisfaction and turnover. It can also cause a bit of overhead as intelligent people look to inject meaning/impact into low impact roles. Also be cautious of the job descriptions when applying. They can be intentionally vague and you may end up doing something you have absolutely no interest in. Far too often have I seen a …

Title: "Nice company bad culture"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Intelligent people, fantastic management, incredible foresight.
Cons: People are human, they are not technology slaves.

Title: "(NON-TECH Role)"
Main Text: Stop thinking Google is a startup. It's clearly not.
Pros: Flexible working schedule
Cons: No specific order:

Title: "Account Manager"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Amazing people, amazing benefits. The company spoils you for sure. I worked on the SMB Team and did connect well with many clients to help them understand the value of AdWords and get as much out of the product as they could.
Cons: Those coming straight out of college, note that having Google on your resume is fantastic, but this role may not be ideal for you if you're not interested in Sales. It requires a lot of cold-calling and internal movement may be harder than you expect.

Title: "Great company to work for focusing on projects with a global scale, but slowing down as it gets bigger."
Main Text: Growth, promotions, and challenges also slowing down as company grows
Pros: Work with very smart people
Cons: Speed of projects slowing down as company gets bigger (more politics, processes to follow, etc.)

Title: "Good"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: Cool environment and everyone is really laid back, yet smart. it has a lot of food.
Cons: sketchy. too many high paying jobs

Title: "Most innovative company of our generation"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Ambitious with global scale and resources
Cons: Speed of execution results in acceptance of short attention spans

Title: "Caring and down to earth employees"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Being able to show up to work dressed causally and not too stressful environment which allowed for growth and learning.
Cons: The entrance exam was very difficult and there were alot of background checks undertaken before the job was actually started. This made for a very stressful first impression but quickly got better as the process progressed.

Title: "The drea"
Pros: Very many; the perks, the salary, the environment. Google knows that it has great culture and gets people thta it knows will continue that tradtiion
Cons: I don't actually feel like the smartest person in the room while im there. its odd for some people (ie me) to adapt to. lol.

Title: "Amazing place to grow a people management career"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Google wants to create and hire the worlds best people managers, and to that end they have more leadership & management trainings, courses, frameworks, and resources than most business schools. And then there are the legendary benefits. Free food, possibly the best health insurance in the country, a great campus completely with gyms, pools, tons of green space, etc. It's a pleasure to be at work.
Cons: Because it's a big company, you have to retain your own "Start-up" drive and motivation. You could just drift along if you aren't proactive. But if you are proactive, wow can you get things done and go places. It just takes a little internal motivation.

Title: "Google was the best place I have ever worked."
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: Perks, perks and more perks.
Cons: Constantly working, not a great work life balance.

Title: "7+ years and still happy"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: People, cultural, food. Depends on which manager and department you are in, but I get control of projects, am not micromanaged and feel I make a real impact.
Cons: Depending on role, can be very narrowly focused at times.

Title: "Amazing experience"
Pros: I can say that one of the most great things here is the smart people. Also excellent ideas everywhere. People also are very friendly. Though the company is getting bigger, work is still having the start up flavor, at least in many teams I know.
Cons: Honestly, I can't see any major cons here in Google. As I mentioned above, it's very pleasant place to work in.

Title: "Nice to work with"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Good work culture, Best package and chance to work on latest technology
Cons: No as such, Very good organisation

Title: "Every bit as good as you hear, but it's still a corporation."
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: An extraordinary supply of very smart, committed, hard-working, talented people. As far as corporate employment goes, Google has to be the diamond standard.
Cons: It's a corporation, so there are definitely some predictable minuses that come with that: it's not as nimble as a start-up, there is some unavoidable bureaucracy, etc.

Title: "good"
Pros: time off policies and food
Cons: long hours at a small office

Title: "Good company to work for"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: smart people, great environment, good chance to advance
Cons: people think they are better than others. Hard to get things done

Title: "Good"
Main Text: - Too many re-orgs just for re-orgs sake, or just to create some work for those managers. One team I worked with were bounced back and forth between 3 different departments within 2 years because of this.
Pros: - Definitely Google provides the best perks...food, events, gym, lots of learning opportunities and cultural activities. It's like a living in a grown up college campus.
Cons: - As my department grew they started having too many middle management (several 'directors' in one team? really?) and it was not really clear why they're here.

Title: "One of the Best"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: You work with the best, meals are better than restaurants, very little micromanagement in my group
Cons: there are some pretty big egos

Title: "Even Remote Office are Great"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: The Google LA office is fantastic. The office is located in Venice just steps from the beach with some of the best facilities including a gym, dog park, roof deck, juice and coffee bar, and an amazing cafe. The office really grasps the Silicon Beach theme of the area
Cons: As Mountain View (HQ) continues to grow, you spend more time collaborating with others over video calls and IM, making it a more inefficient workflow

Title: "Great place to work, but has lost that fast-moving feeling"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: This is the stuff everyone always hears about -- amazing benefits, top pay, free everything all the time in the office, etc. Plus the people are immensely talented and driven. Also, as much flak as the "don't be evil" mantra gets outside of Google, I tend to believe that the company is still largely operated in that way.
Cons: Work-life balance can be tough, specifically in some of the central functions (my experience). I believe a lot of that issue stems from Google being able to attract the absolute best talent in the world who are expecting a fast "startup-like" career trajectory. That's simply not possible anymore given the size of the company, so political maneuvering and passive-aggressive face-time cultures have begun to emerge on …

Title: "The most challenging job I've had in my career."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: The collective intelligence level is off the charts. There is an emphasis on innovation. "We can do it better." There is, generally, an atmosphere of mutual respect. The management walks their talk.
Cons: There can be an atmosphere of one-upsmanship sometimes, when egos come into play. There are a lot of strong egos at Google.

Title: "Great place to grow, great culture, great technology"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: There are great growth opportunities, from internal mobility, internal training, and tuition reimbursement (Google paid for me to go through graduate school). The company has still managed to mostly keep to the "don't be evil" mindset. You're constantly surrounded by really smart people.
Cons: I can't help but feel that I and everyone around me is overqualified for what we do. It's great that internal mobility has been easy for me in my years here, but not great that it sometimes is more about escaping boredom than it is finding new exciting challenges. A co-worker recently left after being here only a few months because he lost patience waiting to have been in his role long enough to be able to move to …

Title: "Dynamic and difficult"
Main Text: I worked at Google part-time (More than a year)
Pros: the offices inspire creativity. most importantly the executives are easily available and this allows for great insight on current projects.
Cons: one of the big issues was the lack of flexibility. it is very difficult if almost impossible to get a few days off to travel ext..

Title: "Making an impact on the world."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: The Mission statement. The Leadership (Larry has done a really good job IMHO of focusing the company). The People, really smart, really nice, usually, there are a couple of bad apples, no system is perfect.
Cons: As the company has gotten larger (been there since 2007) politics has become more prevalent, especially over "control of binaries". Why build on shared platforms when you can't control it (I think it is silly). As you move up the ranks, work life balance gets really screwy as you tend to work with offices all around the world (at least in my case).

Title: "Good but not great"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: Super work culture I say
Cons: Not so super work timings I say

Title: "Sub jobs at google"
Main Text: I worked at Google part-time (More than a year)
Pros: Very good people working there
Cons: They don't hire contractors for permanent positions, they pay very low

Title: "Great company"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Good environment, free food, and you work with the newest innovative products.
Cons: Some people can make you feel dumb.

Title: "Senior Account Strategist"
Main Text: For prospective employees: Hope that you land in the right team. It can be painful to make it through the tough interview process into the company, only to be miserable in your new "home". Good luck.
Pros: Incredibly intelligent, dedicated, motivated colleagues. Friendly environment. Opportunity to try something new after 1 year in a role. Decent benefits. Fun environment.
Cons: Good management can be spotty. The company has grown quickly which has led to some obvious middle management issues, with certain managers who are ill-equipped to take on a team of people and their work.

Title: "technical program manager"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: great benefits and smart people lots of resources to allocate
Cons: hard to make your point across

Title: "This is Disneyland"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: While those who come to Google right out to school may not realize it, Google is really Disneyland. Nowhere else in the world is there a company that offers the same breadth of opportunity, innovation and incredible support for its employees. It is *not* normal anywhere else to have three michelin star dining experiences, easy access dry cleaning and car detailing, gym and massage services and more.
Cons: Perhaps the only con is a result of the 'pro' above. There are a lot of people who have only worked at Google and no where else since graduating from college. There is a lack of appreciation for how lucky we all are.

Title: "Great company, best talents"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Top talented people, great perks, creativities, moonshot projects.
Cons: People are getting less Googley over the years.

Title: "If you want to work at a big company, this is the one to work at"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Great benefits and perks. Lots of challenging problems to solve. Unlimited resources (if you're working on the right things). Most important of all, an incredible mission.
Cons: Lots of underperforming long time employees and managers aren't courageous enough to fire them.

Title: "good environment"
Main Text: I worked at Google part-time (Less than a year)
Pros: the work isn't very tough and depend on your department. Be ready for business trip. Prepare your resume well.
Cons: Be careful being laid off by some reasons you don't know.

Title: "Software Engineering for Engineers by Engineers"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Google gets that the less you have to pay attention to peripheral stuff and leave campus, the more you get done in a day. This means that on-site benefits are valuable and easy to access including health care, exercise, and personal care. It's a challenging environment that will make you play your A game.
Cons: No matter what position you're in, coding is key. If you do develop skill in at least one programming language, there are limited opportunities.

Title: "Good place to change the world"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: The Company is Innovative and resourceful
Cons: The Company is too big for you to know what each team is working on

Title: "No better place to grow"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: The perks and environment of the company are well known, but the resources for professional growth are sometimes overlooked. There is no better company in tech or the Valley to accelerate your career and grow personally or professionally.
Cons: Based on the team that you are on, it may be difficult to see the impact that you are having on the billions that use Google. That motivation has to come from yourself.

Title: "What an amazing place to work!"
Pros: The energy, the people, the high level of talent.
Cons: It's hard to stop working sometimes!

Title: "Great company, but getting too big."
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Smart people, great perks, and proud on working with greatest company in the world for now. Good life/work balance in general.
Cons: Hard to get high impact work approved and done. Sometimes too much re-org and too little long term vision could hurt an organization with substantial size. Mid-management usually is the weak link in the system to constraint innovation, vision and productivity. Promotion system is kind of broken - we have managers/senior people in the team who made bad decisions about product but still got promoted at the exact the …

Title: "very satisfied"
Pros: very friendly and mentored a lot
Cons: lot of people hard to spend time on one project

Title: "Good place to work with smart people"

Title: "Great place to work"

Title: "The only company to work on this planet."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
