Title: "Awesome"
Main Text: - Good work-life balance so far. Hardly anyone works at the weekend in my team and most people are out of the office between 5 and 6.
Pros: They treat people like adults - not checking up on your every move. There is a great sense of humour in the way they do things. The salary is great, and best of all, you get to make a difference to 100's of millions of people.
Cons: It's easy to feel intimidated by the talent surrounding you.

Title: "Overpaid DoubleClickers beware."
Main Text: No opinion of CEO
Pros: Awesome perks, access to great technology and resources, surrounded by very smart people.

Title: "Cut throat, privileged co-workers, and burn out inevitiable"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Great benefits and perks depending on the office you're located in. Larger offices have more "Google" options like gym, robust cafes, massages, and ample training classes. The salary is also competitive when you factor in all of the benefits. However, many other companies are becoming "Googley" so beware that it isn't the same it was 5 years ago. All departments are different but the best ones everyone wants to get …
Cons: You will get burned out eventually which is why the majority of the employees don't last more than 3 years. You are expected to work day and night, no matter what role you're in, and be available when away on vacations. Management will stress over and over that they wan you to check out for PTO, but when you do, it backfires and I've had 9 different managers and all were the same. I believe it comes from the culture …

Title: "Only Hype, maybe it was a good company a few years ago. No longer."
Main Text: Stop canceling projects, too many things going on, can`t get anything right.
Pros: Good co-workers, smart people move on fast.
Cons: After all the interviews, they have nothing to offer you other than status for your resume.

Title: "Excellent environment for engineers."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Google has managed to recruit an excellent community of engineers. Engineers are friendly, and very knowledgeable. Generally, management has made the community collaborative, rather than competitive or contentious. It is a wonderful environment where your software skills are valued and nurtured, and where you can learn from your peers, some of whom are leaders in various sections of the field.
Cons: There are few "cons" to Google. One possible thing that can be mentioned here is that Google is a very large company, and it is somewhat easy to find a corner in which to lose oneself. Another possible knock is that Google has a small number of allowed languages. If you want to code in languages other than C++, Java, Go or Python, you'll probably not have much support at Google.

Title: "Great job, great culture and great perks"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: The perks are unbelievable. The culture is awesome. Lots of great travel opportunities
Cons: People are really pretentious. Company is too big now, you're not contributing much

Title: "Best company in the world, but that doesn't mean all work you do will be equally interesting"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Amazing people, learning opportunities and perks. Interesting own culture you can learn a lot from. Every programmer should experience working here.
Cons: As hard as they work at cutting through bureaucracy, it remains a large company with all the problems that gives. If you're the kind of person that likes to just get things done instead of guiding your project through the companies processes, you may get frustrated.

Title: "Great company to work for if you like to stay on your toes."
Main Text: No opinion of CEO
Pros: The daily benefits are great -- flexible schedule, free meals, and a young, exciting culture.
Cons: The company does not place a lot of value on Temporary Vendor Contractors. They are seen as disposable employees with no room to grow.

Title: "Challenging and enjoyable"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Great benefits and a friendly environment where professional and personal growth is encouraged.
Cons: I don't think there are any cons.

Title: "Great salary and benefits, slowly morphing into a bureaucratic behemoth."
Main Text: -A serious sense of entitlement/hubris exists throughout, most prevalent on campus where recent college grads operate in a non-reality.
Pros: -For a large corporation Google is still amazingly open and transparent about company objectives and results.
Cons: -In most orgs there's a glass ceiling for non MBAs. There's too much emphasis on pedigree vs real-world experience.

Title: "Global Business Org"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: Google has the most amazing people - super smart, driven, good-natured, great pay & benefits/perks. So much amazing innovation all around you!
Cons: In the sales org, a few things to be wary of: a) the culture has gotten overly political and b) aggressive. I think this starts with Nikesh and works its way through the org

Title: "Great company"
Pros: salary, tasks, culture, perks, leadership
Cons: promotions, decision making process, office culture

Title: "Overall A Great Place"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Great culture, Great leaders, Amazing transparency
Cons: Slowly becoming a big company, bit of red tape everywhere.

Title: "A memorable and valuable experience, obviously great perks"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Great talented co-workers, excellent perks, generally busy at work.
Cons: Management of the department could have been stronger, clearer direction, more transparent, rewarding based more so on merit.

Title: "Best big company you can find out there"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Smart and collaborative coworkers, great benefits and perks, open and fun environment.
Cons: Lack of opportunities for growth, especially if you're not an engineer in a distributed office.

Title: "Marketing Associate"
Pros: People actually care here. That's what I loved about working at Google; every day I came in and felt like the people I worked with genuinely wanted to know how my life/career was going. This was a fantastic feeling, and it made me excited to return every day.
Cons: Difficult to get good work noticed. Everyone is very smart there of course, and so it isn't always easy to get your work shown at the highest levels.

Title: "Full of the worst people from Microsoft"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: All the usual good stuff about Google: free food and good comp.
Cons: Google opened the Kirkland office to poach from Microsoft and Amazon. Looks like they got what they wished for. The office and Google internally is just brimming with politics and useless processes now. All the good Engineers have/will leave very shortly.

Title: "Amazing place to work"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: Challenging work with many different projects to work on.
Cons: None. You just have to be very proactive about advancing your career which I actually enjoy

Title: "Great company"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Amazing technology. Great environment to learn in. High expectations. You need to be able to upramp quickly and come up to speed on emerging bleeding edge technologies in short order.
Cons: The hours can be very long. Google has a strong Not Invented Here mentality. So you will work with a lot of Google-only code. Everything from the development environment, build system, code review tool, automated test tool are in house only tools. They are all custom developed.

Title: "Great job with excellent benefits"
Main Text: However, it is up to you to find out what you can do to contribute to the project.
Pros: Working here has been very fulfilling. There are lots of interesting people doing very cool work that motivates you everyday to get to the office.
Cons: Lot of work. There is no balance at times.

Title: "Too big for a rapid career growth"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Time offs, Benefits, Office culture
Cons: Career Growth, Appreciates only launches.

Title: "Work hard, Play harder"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Within my team, we have a particularly flat hierarchy, though it can be quite hierarchical when interfacing with executives above our team. We have opportunities for mutual feedback with coworkers, a strong focus on increasing team well-being/happiness, lots of team bonding events, and a high drive towards personal growth. The overall company has an atmosphere of conviviality that is energizing.
Cons: Work-life balance can be a bit difficult because of the pressure from executives outside our team; however, leads work to be role models of work-life balance in order to encourage associates to manage their schedules as necessary to protect personal happiness.

Title: "Awesome place to work."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Great people and big challenges to work on. They really take care of their people.
Cons: There's a lot going on and sometimes work/life balance suffers.

Title: "Great company but chaos and churn can be grinding"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Excellent compensation, benefits, perks, possibility of travel, variety, opportunities to take on lots of different projects, freedom to define the scope and direction of work, smart people.
Cons: Leadership with ADD, constant change of direction/priorities, reorgs, churn, turnover, duplication of effort, lack of accountability, chaos, etc. that sometimes leads to inferior results, unfinished work, unequal treatment, and burnout. In some offices, overcrowding and poor physical conditions.

Title: "Google work"
Pros: Great culture, people, food and environment. Very rigorous approach to product planning and maybe most importantly a transparent culture where people are encouraged to give feedback and dig in where they're interested.
Cons: It's gotten big. People who have dreams of working at startups will find out that Google is now (and has been for a while) a very large company with lots of divisions and layers.

Title: "This was a great Place to work"
Pros: This was a great place to work
Cons: The usual things you run into with a large company, nothing to be super worried about.

Title: "The Best"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: The diversity of opportunity. Google touches so many industries from ad-tech to consumer software and hardware. There is something for everyone at Google and it's very easy to find a role on a product that you truly care about. The culture is incredible and work-life balance is great.
Cons: If you live in SF and work in MTV the commute is long. Otherwise there are very few cons to working at Google. They've created an incredible corporate environment.

Title: "Great"
Pros: Good, Wonderful, Exciting, Wonderful, NB!
Cons: Nothing, I love it. Nothing else to say.

Title: "Inspiring technology, amazing people & perks, a few issues"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: - Google's products have amazing scale and impact - very inspiring
Cons: - Manager quality varies immensely from very strong to very weak; bad managers are not dinged if their team delivers strong results (even if Google bleeds talent as a result)

Title: "If you are ambitious you CAN have huge impact!!"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: lots of opportunities to make a difference, really smart people all around, great culture. Great opportunities to work cross platforms and cross geographies.
Cons: Success/Recognition != necc translate to comp and promotions. Politics is very real. There are some really bad VPs who need to be avoided.

Title: "Great place to start career, tough to navigate"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Google was a great place to launch my career. As someone who was interested in launching my own company, I cannot overstate what it means to have Google on my resume. I've gotten interviews at top startup incubators and meetings with VC's based off the Google creds alone.
Cons: Upward mobility within the sales organization is difficult, particularly if you aren't keen on organizational politics. It's very separate from the rest of the Google and has the feel/culture of a consulting firm rather than an org trying to work on challenging and interesting problems. It's so far removed from the business, they've actually moved sales to a completely new campus they built. It literally feels like …

Title: "nice place to work there"

Title: "Great tech company and generally positive culture"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Can't speak to whole company, but my team treated my well. Obviously a ton of perks/benefits and generally good comp. Very comfy living. Would be hard to leave here except to go to a startup.
Cons: You can get complacent. Climbing the ladder is becoming tougher and tougher. Expect a title downgrade if you come here laterally. Fair amount of bureaucracy, though not crippling given the size.

Title: "Great place to work and to grow"

Cons: It is a big place and it is easy to feel at the bottom of the pile

Title: "Awesome Company to Work For"

Cons: As Google grows larger more process and bureaucracy set in. Unfortunately the highly selective hiring process has a high false negative rate.

Title: "Great company that is now a really big company"

Cons: More and more narrow work, increasingly bureaucratic

Title: "Awesome"

Title: "a good company to work for"

Pros: talented coworkers; good food; unique recruiting process that is fair; opportunity to work in different teams
Cons: long working hours; feel like a minor part in the big picture; new team opportunity is taken before posted for public knowledge.

Title: "Google is the best place in the world to work - if you're an engineer"

Almost all the cafes are top notch and the microkitches are fully stocked. During my time there, I met some of the most powerful people in the world, was entertained by some of the greatest bands and met some of my favorite authors. The annual holiday party is also exceptional and no cost …

Title: "Amazing company with great vision"

Pros: There is no doubt that Google is one of the most amazing companies in the world. Your co-workers tend to be incredibly nice, hard working, interesting people.
Cons: It's really big and thus you have to do a lot of internal "selling" to move ideas forward. Once you have sufficient buy-in, Google can move quickly, but it can take a long time to get there.

Title: "A great place to work"

Title: "Greatest place ever"

Title: "Best company to start your career in."

Cons: Easy to get lost in the crowd. So many extraordinary people surrounding can sometimes be overwhelming and get to your nerves. But the company has become so big that nobody would care if you just came to work to eat, gossip and take your paycheck.

Title: "Great!"

Title: "came in excited, left very disappointed"

My team members were confused about who even their new managers would be. While no one expected handouts, it was hard to find someone even interested in assisting those who came on with temporary roles. It was starting from scratch to find a place in the big Google world.

Title: "Google's amazing (and big)!"

Title: "good company"

Title: "Great company to work for"

Title: "Good place overall"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Great pay and it just comes with performance and promotions, you don't need to negotiate it. You get the chance to work with and learn from some amazing people. Very high code quality, not just at the level of coding style or individual classes, but the overall system architecture, things tend to be really thought through, stupid things don't happen.
Cons: Google's tech stack is big and complex. You will be spending a lot of time figuring out how to plug together various systems and APIs. You may be spending a lot of time looking at various status pages, trying to understand whether your tasks are doing what they should with acceptable performance and why not and which obscure configuration option you need to tweak to make them. A lot of what you will need to learn to …

Title: "The best there is"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: No company is perfect, but Larry and Sergey aim at running a great one. Free food is just the beginning, although parents of small kids will find it especially liberating to bring them over for dinner after a hard day of work rather than cooking.
Cons: Mandatory code reviews create a government like culture where people can "filibuster" something they don't like by just whining and refusing to approve the contribution until the author gives in.

Title: "ok"

Title: "Great place to work"

Title: "Great Company to work with"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)

Title: "Despite its size, still a rewarding and inspiring place to work"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Google takes on big, audacious, challenging problems that give you the opportunity to impact the world. You're surrounded by brilliant people who work hard, get things done, and inspire you to elevate your game. There are inspiring, world-changing projects all around you, and even if you have not yet had the opportunity to work on one, I find satisfaction just being able to observe from the inside. Larry has done an …
Cons: The company is huge, there's no denying it. Larry and his team do a great job of keeping things nimble and making the company feel much smaller than it is, but no one can say it feels like a small company anymore. In a company filled with hard workers and overachievers, it's easy to get too caught up on pay, the performance review process, and getting promoted. This is one reason why maintaining a good work-life …

Title: "Fantastic"

Title: "Great company in every way."
Main Text: Show More
Pros: This company is exceptional because it realizes the true value of human capital. Employees are treated well, encouraged to grow in their profession and experience work on projects outside of their normal expertise.
Cons: I cannot think of any whatsoever. This company is superlative in every way. If I absolutely had to come up with a con, I would say that the worst part of working at Google is the innate guilt I experience when others talk about their jobs and then ask about mine. It is hard to have to explain to others how amazing a workplace Google provides, and to witness the incredulous looks others give.

Title: "Not what you expect"

Title: "Huge Freedom and smart people"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 8 years)
Pros: Huge freedom to pursue the projects I want. Smart people who are information sponges. Free food and excellent work-life balance.

Title: "Great company to work for"
Main Text: - easy to get fact with so many free food

Title: "Great company, but horrible team"
Main Text: work-life balance, healthy food and snacks.
Pros: Free food (Breakfast, lunch and dinner), napping pods, volleyball, basketball courts. Outdoor field, company events, free gym, lots of other perks.
Cons: I felt that moving around involved a lot of politics. I always felt like my manager was trying to keep me and others from moving up on the chain. This was very horrible. After I got a new lead, it was a little better, but my time there was limited as I had already put in my 2 weeks notice just before I got my new lead.

Title: "Great place to work, AFTER you advance your career."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Great culture. Great food. Lots of energetic people with a variety of interests. Whatever you're into, you'll find a group of people to do it with at Google, whether it's ports, fitness, music, or racing.
Cons: Managers don't seem to be incentivized to help you advance your career. The promotion process is the biggest pain you can imagine, and completely self-propelled. If you're not the type that likes to promote yourself, you'll be stuck at the bottom for a long time.

Title: "a good company"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Good technology, smart people, can move within company with descent support.

Title: "Great"

Title: "Simply amazing workplace with incredible opportunities"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: We work with some of the smartest, most ambitious, and intelligent people around. The problems that we tackle are have great impact worldwide. The work is incredibly challenging and interesting. We're constantly told to think bigger. We really are trying to change the world.
Cons: There are many projects that get rejected or shutdown because they aren't Google-scale. Any of these projects that gets rejected would be really successful if it was created by a startup. This also means that the bar for launch is much higher.

Title: "good company"

Title: "Fabulous place to work"

Title: "Googlers play hard and work hard"

Overall I would say it is one of the best companies I have ever worked for!

Title: "Challenging and fun."

It's rewarding to know that your code is being executed millions of times a day when people use Google's products. Perks and pay are awesome. Equity you get in form of restricted stock units are growing in value by leaps and bounds. Lots of flexibility in work/life balance (I work from home one day a week to avoid the …
Cons: Commute is terrible if you live in San Francisco and work in Mountain View. May be less fun and rewarding if you aren't on an interesting team/product. In a huge company, some people find they have difficulty feeling like they're making an impact.

Title: "Love the founders, excessive growth and middle management destroyed the culture."

Pros: Benefits, Compensation, cash to burn, pockets of innovation remain in the company. The founders are strong and are genuine.
Cons: Poor middle management, inexperience and arrogance made life very difficult. Too much time playing and not enough time delivering. Academic prejudice runs deep, politics and back-stabbing is the norm.

Title: "Amazing Place"

Title: "Great office, small box..."
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time
Pros: The perks here are fantastic obviously. Great co-workers (for the most part) and the office is absolutely amazing.
Cons: The work you do has varying levels of impact and again, depending on your role, the chance that your work will change is minimal. You are essentially a cog in the big Google machine. Don't kid yourself into thinking that this is a startup-y kind of place, it's not.

Title: "Great company"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Great people, lots of opportunity, being creative is highly valued. The products are very interesting to work on and people give good feedback
Cons: Big company so it takes time to know who's doing what. Difficult to be the best of the best in a place that's full of great talent.

Title: "Amazing place to work, but everyone overqualified for their position"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Best product vision and execution in the world
Cons: There are so many talented people, there is a huge backlog for promotions and challenging assignments. At this point, most people are overpaid for what they do, so there is not a lot of attrition, making the backlog longer.

Title: "Great!"
Pros: Quick interview and placement. Great access to perks.
Cons: It's a temp job so that's the downside.

Title: "It was a great experience."

Cons: The expectations to do great things is difficult for a career person who happens to have a family with you children. Time management is a must.

Title: "All glam, just a cog in another corporate wheel"

Pros: Great food, smart people, and a healthy work-life balance. Did I mention that the food is really great? Because it is.
Cons: Super hierarchical structure, not a meritocracy. At the end of the day, you're just a cog in a big money-making machine, so your work will be not that interesting. There's a ton of bureaucracy to deal with as well.

Title: "Couldn't ask for a better job out of college..."

Title: "Nice Place"

Title: "Great place to work"
Main Text: I have been working at Google (More than a year)

Title: "No Complaints--Everything is Great"

Title: "Great company, difficult transition post acquisition"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Free food, amazing people, amazing vision - almost everything about this company is a pro. This is an incredible place to work.

Title: "Ate lunch with Al Gore, ate lunch on 60 Minutes, worked hard, worked late, missed the ipo."
Main Text: If you want to try to get a full time job here, don't have other plans for a year. AT ALL.
Pros: I was a contractor, and you must know that as a contractor your number one job is to make yourself invaluable to Google for an entire year. Be there early, stay late, do everything your're asked to and three or four times that. Go out with your coworkers, go out with your boss, become a Googler even though you aren't. Yes the pay sucks, but you have an opportunity to get your foot in the door. Introduce yourself to …
Cons: Sneaking into company events. Explaining that you're not with adwords but you actually have a meaningful project.

Title: "Google has a great developer editing software. Better than Apple's in my opinion."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)

Cons: Takes a lot of time to make an app with this software!?!

Title: "Working at Google makes other jobs pale in comparison."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Great Talent, Great Perks, Great Vision!!! I wake up every morning excited about coming to work. The people are friendly and supportive. The management is hands off and allows for a solid work/life balance.
Cons: I cannot think of any cons of working at Google beside the fact that I am not allowed to tell anyone what I do, where I do it, or how long I'll be doing it for. haha

Title: "Admn"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Engineers have a great time ! Very innovation focused.
Cons: Nothing new coming up that will take on the market like search did.

Title: "My Review"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Lots of free food. Lots of cafes. Lots of trees. Lots of fresh air. Lots of buildings. Lots of smart people to work with and hard problems to solve.
Cons: Campus is too big need to walk so far. Too many cafes to choose from. Too many buildings to visit.

Title: "Software Engineer"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Exciting work, constantly changing and evolving work
Cons: Start up life might wear you down

Title: "Not your usual organization"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Very casual, great environment, smart people.
Cons: Very little structure, wasteful money, over hire people that are not needed.

Title: "Awesome!"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: Working at Google was a Great experience
Cons: I'd argue that there aren't any cons

Title: "Best place to work I have worked at."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Culture at the company is great! People are supportive of each other, working toward a common goal.
Cons: It may be tough at times, as you are competing with very smart people. It feels humbling from time to time!

Title: "Still great, but changing quickly"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Smart co-workers, unbeatable perks, innovation, and the feeling that the company will lead the technology world for a long time. Individual talent is usually respected and there is a great deal of transparency and open debate.
Cons: Increasing demand to achieve results is taking stress to uncomfortable levels, and some managers are having a hard time handling it. Difficult to move to a role out of your area of expertise.

Title: "Great place"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Food, people, campus, problems are interesting
Cons: very difficult to advance in the company cult-like

Title: "Googs"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: They treat their staff very well, pay and perks are fantastic. The co-workers were all very smart and you will learn a lot.
Cons: No ownership of work, unclear career trajectories, hard to have impact (small fish in big pond syndrome)

Title: "The People are what make Google Google"
Main Text: - great resources to assist with continued education and career advancement
Pros: - You're trusted to solve complex problems with some of the most talented minds
Cons: The only con I would site is that it's a highly competitive place, which is to be expected at a company full of Type A personalities.

Title: "The best place to work at!!"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: Lots of interesting work. Culture is amazing. Company really takes care of employees
Cons: Highly competitive. Ramp up takes a long time. Promotions are a little bit hard to get.

Title: "Had a good time at Google lots and lots of things to do and great groups and products"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Lots and lots of perks plus salary is really good
Cons: You must throw your team mates under the bus to get ahead.

Title: "Awesome"
Pros: Food taste really good and is free
Cons: Competition can make the work tough

Title: "Good"
Pros: Smart people work here so its enjoyable
Cons: Too big already, not a startup feel

Title: "Fantastic Workplace"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: You're working for Google, one of the most diverse workplace in the world. They have slides, inside the buildings. Plus the people you work with are fantastic people, you learn a lot from them and their cultures.
Cons: there are really no cons to working in Google. Although it can be tiring at times.

Title: "Exhausting with no feedback"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Resume building, energy of company perks are so so.,
Cons: Arrogant employees, better than thou, work you to exhaustion and are never honest about performance

Title: "Great for early 20 something or someone ok without a work/life balance"
Main Text: Truly ask people why they are leaving - you paid a lot to bring talent on board, identify what went wrong.
Pros: Lots of energetic people that work at a different pace. Idea conception, to testing, to production can be as little as a day, in various fields.
Cons: No telecommuting - pretty much the rule.

Title: "Great experience but like everywhere else."
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Excellent benefits ticks all the boxes and some,, forward-thinking, nice people overall, opportunities to learn about numerous products;
Cons: unclear paths to advancement; Goals not always articulated; numerous different managers a different one every 6 months; can feel "cultish" though it would classify as a nice cult

Title: "Best company ever"
Pros: this company is great for opportunities and chances to grow professionally. working with the team is great and good work balance
Cons: i cannot think about downsides

Title: "Kool Aide Central"
Pros: Great quality of life on campus
Cons: Very cult like, uncomfortable if you don't want to buy in.

Title: "Great first job out of college with smartest people I've met. Great company for college grads and people with children."
Main Text: All things considered, workload was manageable and work/life balance was great.
Pros: Got to work with some of the smartest people I've met.
Cons: Entry-level support positions have little job mobility and lack the glamour of other Google departments

Title: "Pm"
Pros: Great work environment. Great colleagues to work with
Cons: No cons. Company is great to work for

Title: "Challenging and rewarding"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: You already know about the perks and remuneration, so I'll talk about the real pros: all-star coworkers, difficult problems to sink your teeth into, and the reward of being able to provide amazing services to people.
Cons: Google's gotten big. Very big. With human nature the way it is, the size leads to the challenges you'd expect -- silos, difficulty coordinating, diffusion of responsibility, culture, etc.

Title: "Best Perks"
Main Text: 3. Things change very fast, you have to keep learning no matter how fast learner you are.
Pros: 1. All great environment and facilities to do whatever you like to do
Cons: 1. Too much peer pressure.

Title: "Excellent employer with many interesting projects."
Main Text: The company (and internet advertising in general) seems to get a bad rap from external parties this days, which I believe is undeserved. We seem to do a bad job controlling perception of the Google brand.
Pros: The cutting edge tech infrastructure is a playground for any software engineer, and the absolute best stack you could imagine working with. The work environment is very entrepreneurial, and the compensation is easily and quickly adjusted for good performance.
Cons: The culture can be a little inward-looking IMO, also many employees are unprofessional and/or rude on internal communication channels.

Title: "Experience at Google"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Food, benefits, work-life balance, Flexibility to move teams.
Cons: No Ladder growth, many misuse WFH option

Title: "Awesome Company"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Great perks, great people, and really challenging problems to work on. There's a work hard, play hard mentality that makes for a very satisfying career.
Cons: Some people don't have a life outside of work and have similar expectations of those around them. Management works to avoid bureaucracy, but as the company grows it's hard to avoid. The rapid pace of hiring has definitely changed the feel of the company.

Title: "Interdisciplinary"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: I met some of the nicest and smartest people on the planet. Very interdisciplinary and quite the engaging environment.
Cons: As with all companies, sometimes there are issues with managers and coworkers, but we are all adults and know how to deal with such conflict.

Title: "great perks, good people, ok job"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: - they treat their people really well
Cons: - the work is not always stimulating or consequential

Title: "Working at Google, while challenging, is incredibly fulfilling and you can be sure of getting honest feedback"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time
Pros: Free everything. Really, everything!!! Free laundry, free car for a day, free food, free massages, heck, they even throw in a free annual medical physical right on campus
Cons: Career progression is a key problem at Google. As the company is so young, so many of the initial employees are still working there, which leaves very little opportunity for new hires to climb the ladder

Title: "Software engineer for 2 and a half years."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Having a manager who believes in you defining the vision, execution, and testing for a project.
Cons: Working on systems where 98% of it is optimized and you are looking for the 2% efficiency improvement.

Title: "magnificient"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: you are free to do whatever you wan't to do at any time :) it was a great experience, i would recommend it to my friends, cousins, anyone!
Cons: i see no cons, everything is simple just like the website. everything is just perfect, even the food.

Title: "Amazing colleagues and the company makes it very comfortable to work there."
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Best in class colleagues, big/interesting problems to solve, great perks, competitive salaries, easy to transfer between roles internally.
Cons: I worked at Google for over 6 years and saw a lot of growth during this period. The resulting bureaucracy could be frustrating and certain decisions were nearly impossible to reverse; I often heard statements to the effect of "we analyzed this a few years ago and our decision was X, so we're not going to revisit it now."

Title: "Brilliant Company"
Pros: Google provides incredible perks that really boost morale. All of the social events allow employees to meet colleagues from other areas, which truly fosters innovation. I worked with very smart people who are driven, which pushed me to pursue more of my goals.
Cons: The amazing benefits and incredibly stimulating work environment makes it difficult to leave.

Title: "A powerful, forward-thinking large company."
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Focused on long-term investments, focused on changing the world (versus creating silly social toy apps like the rest of the Valley)
Cons: Massively large scale means slower development

Title: "good company!!"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: great innovation-- changing the world
Cons: very intimidating-- you're surrounded by some of the smartest people

Title: "Best place to work for!!"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Amazing food and all the amenities. Looks like you are in a resort.
Cons: Not enough interesting work. Kind of boring. Google is lacking on innovation.

Title: "Fantastic career growth experience"
Main Text: - Long hiring process made it difficult to build up your team
Pros: - Great work experience
Cons: - Politics and bureaucracy were creeping in by 2009 which made life as a middle manager difficult

Title: "One of the best companies to work for."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Great benefits and compensation, very enjoyable work environment. Open and candid company culture. Opportunities to make big impact. Access to some of the brightest co-workers and a lot to learn from. Upper management still thinking bold and big.
Cons: As the company gets bigger the management is becoming more top-down, resulting in a lot of products or teams not getting enough internal traction to make impact.

Title: "Software Engineer"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Competitive compensations; talented peers; open work environment; flexible work time; easy to change product/service to work on
Cons: Relatively slow to get promoted compared to small-sized companies.

Title: "Good place to work"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Quality of work/projects/people will depend on what team you land up in; great benefits and perks
Cons: Long hours -- people check and send email at all hours of the day!

Title: "Great Experience"
Main Text: I worked at Google part-time

Title: "Great employer, great perks"

Title: "Great culture, great work, huge impact"
Main Text: Very good work-life balance.

Title: "Good place to work but not always the best people to work with."

Pros: Great benefits and solid pay. Interesting work. Smart people. Always on the cutting edge of technology.

I was astounded by the superiority complex numerous full-time "Googlers" had toward the temps, vendors, and contractors Google also employs. This attitude also was exhibited toward employees who came to Google via acquisitions. Google …

Title: "It is the best place whether employed or a consultant"
Pros: Its freaking google its amazing literally.
Cons: paid less because consultant very part time

Title: "benefits great, but work-life balance isn't"
Main Text: * Doing too many things, which detract from the quality of products and dwindle resources

Title: "Awesome people, becoming too bureaucratic"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Awesome people to work with
Cons: Getting too bureaucratic and losing original vision

Title: "A great place to work if you are a workaholic"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 8 years)
Pros: Great people, exceptional benefits and perks, lovely campuses.
Cons: Long hours, employee evaluation system is based on a bell curve, so even a rockstar team has employees "below expectations".

Title: "Amazing people, amazing environment, okay salaries."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: The obvious pros are the perks, but they extend beyond the well known free food and slides. They do great 401k matching, have great health care, offer a lot of extra-curricular like activities for employees. There is a lot to do and they work to keep employees happy.
Cons: The salary is less than you can get at similar companies. If you don't care about or take advantage of the perks, its especially obvious.

Title: "Great"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Brilliant minds, lots of interesting work, nobody is bad at what they do. If you find yourself not on an interesting project, it's not hard to move
Cons: There really aren't any. The commute maybe, depending on where you live? But that's goign to be a problem anywhere.

Title: "Google is a great place, but I've had a mixed experience - it's sometimes hard to be a happy person if everyone is great"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Work with great people, awesome salary, benefits, the place is chock full of good people. There is a very advanced internal software infrastructure for you to learn about and use, that will be more capable in many ways than any place in the world. And Google has world leader work loads - everyone says that but its true for the big g.
Cons: Hard to deal with being average, if you were a super-achiever in your old job (most of the not-great people were weeded at interview time, as well as many other good people).

Title: "Need to be in California to have a Career"
Main Text: Definitely a bit company that is still innovating but feeling like Microsoft more and more everyday.
Pros: Work with very bright people who are passionate about what they do.
Cons: The company is huge and the bureaucracy has ballooned. It is very hard to get things done.

Title: "great"

Title: "Great to become world-class at one specific thing, very difficult for non-engineers to transition out of roles"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)

Title: "Everything it's cracked up to be"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: - Brilliant people: I have tremendous respect for my co-workers and management in the organization.
Cons: - It is a large company, so the scale means development will be slower, albeit still proceeding at a much faster pace than at comparably sized company.

Title: "Google is awesome"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Work with smart people on projects that are changing the world. Future thinking and innovative, always something that will surprise you. Great benefits and life experiences. Everything you do gets noticed in the press. Fun that family/friends know where you work. Campus is like college, there are activities for every interest and all kinds of interesting people to meet.
Cons: Bureaucracy of a large company. Lots of scrutiny in the press on anything Google does.

Title: "Great learning experience with great people"
Pros: Lots of interactions with very smart people who're enthusiastic about their work, great perks, and the impactful project.
Cons: There was a bit too nerdy atmosphere, and the company was too basically too big to get to know even what's going on in nearby teams.

Title: "Spent 5+ years in Marketing - it's different from being an engineer at Google"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Awesome people, hands down. Peers and colleagues. Some of the brightest people. Company policies on expenses, perks, family, pets, etc. - all outstanding.
Cons: Salary isn't the best on the market. Google knows it can pay less than it has to, because people want to work for it. Google has departments working on formulas meant to pay you as little as possible. Huge fight to get to the top - everyone is in a race. A culture of overachievers, which means you have to sacrifice personal and social life to move up the ranks. I've seen amazing rates of burnout among marketing. Too …

Title: "There were great perks but surprised at the lack of data in b2c marketing"

Cons: At least in my department - processes were not very streamlined and created inefficiencies and unnecessary work.

Title: "Fun and challenging place to work."

Title: "Good perks, but living in the area is too expensive"

Title: "Great!"

Title: "Excellent work environment but your relationship with your manager will determine your fate"

Title: "Awesome place to work"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Code is available to all employees and thus no tribalism across teams.
Cons: Too much infrastructure to grapple initially

Title: "Good company for engineers, strong work culture, company getting too big & hierarchical"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: - Set the standard for employee benefits and perks (cafeteria food options, shuttle, holiday parties, holiday gifts, gym, etc.)
Cons: - As a very engineering centric company, not as many other resources go towards the supporting functions. Engineers have a clear career path, yet this can be difficult to navigate if you're in another role. However, there is much internal mobility.

Title: "Google still an incredible place to work"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Had to add my own thoughts after seeing so many concerns about work-life balance at Google. I joined Google about a year ago after many years in mid-tier management consulting. For me, it's been a refreshing return to work-life balance. No, that doesn't mean I work 35 hr weeks. I'm often at Google before 7am and sometimes stay past 7pm. I work hard because I want to be the best in my profession, because I believe I …
Cons: Let's be honest: Google spoils it's employees. We're all fortunate to work here. The thing I worry about most is whether I'm making a real difference. Google has such a legacy, and such infinite resources, that it can be a little overwhelming trying to figure out if you're taking full advantage of the opportunity. For example, I'm guessing that the job posting that started my career here had maybe 100 other …

Title: "A perfect workplace for tech lover greedy to learn the best technology in industry."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Less workload, high quality team, extensible webbed set of projects, great opportunities to learn, free 15 pound meals ..... many more ....
Cons: None as such which can be specified in particular as the industry is best place to work at in US and anywhere else in the world.

Title: "I can't think of anywhere I'd rather be."

Title: "Great first job out of college! Serious disconnect going on within management."
Main Text: Show More
Pros: It's like working and playing at a university campus that happens to be called Google. Awesome perks to appease those in their 20s and 30s. Great for living up your fresh-out-of-college years. The first few years feel new, shiny, and amazing. Google is practically mecca for engineers.
Cons: That appeal fades over time, though, and it's very difficult to grow inside the company. You'll wonder what good is your Ivy League degree (or similar) in a place like Google where the company recruits and boasts the "best and brightest" simply because it can afford to. You're not able to put your hard work, talent, and aspiration to good use or to anything meaningful. Google is definitely not all that awesome for …

Title: "software engineer"

Title: "Nice place to start, but maybe not the best place to stay"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)

Title: "Absolutely amazing - This is what every company should aspire to be like"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: casual and comfortable, free gourmet food, recreational equipment, genuinely friendly people, smart coworkers who work hard and won't give you the "could you explain __?" stall tactic (or they're bright enough they're never confused about what you mean)
Cons: very rigid upper management structure and company policies. even if someone can do more, you're limited by your role, access, etc. as typical at large companies, departments are very compartmentalized and there's not too much cross-functional interaction. Google also tends to hire more based on credentials first, personality second, and experience third. I've seen bright people who spend 8 hrs doing something that …

Title: "Fast paced and loose culture that encourages risk taking. Plenty of perks."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Great challenges, not a lot of politics in the area I work. Opportunities arise if you are resourceful to go work in start up like environments within a very large company.
Cons: Sometimes a bit fragmented in priorities and the pace can be challenging at times as it's pretty relentless

Title: "great"
Main Text: I have been working at Google part-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Lots of free time and I really got into shape but thats ok, because now I'm a happy person.
Cons: I never did go home to much it was a bit difficult to stand the amount of programmers that were not profesional at all.

Title: "Tough but interesting place to be a lawyer"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: The work is cutting edge and career-making. By the contacts you make and the experience you can have, as well as the name on your resume, it is door-opening. You will work with one of the smartest collections of people in the world, with every perk known in employment. One thing I'll say is that shared offices are often seen as a negative but are actually quite a plus for most people.
Cons: For the lawyer hired post IPO, the pay is low and the hours are long. I'd prefer better compensation than all the perks - many of which I could not really use because I was working too hard. Things change frequently and working with some of the smartest people comes with a price, which is often a high level of arrogance - even disdain for lawyers. Maybe it's what keeps the Google business more successful. Aside from …

Title: "A very unique place to work..."
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: The people. The environment. The technology. Working at Google is really a unique experience that makes you grow.
Cons: The growing speed of such organization might generate some management problems if not properly handled.

Title: "Hard work; great people."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Benefits, perks, and the people. Everyone around you is smart and tend to get along well with one another. The benefits are great and I only pay roughly 250/mo for a large family.
Cons: Stress from being over worked, long hours at times, some people don't work well with others, and meetings are aplenty.

Title: "amazing place to work at."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: The best part about working at google is the culture. Everyone is friendly and amazingly smart which has inspired me to be innovative in the way I approach projects.
Cons: The only downside for working at Google is being surrounded by delicious free food which i always want to eat. I've gained some weight while working here but at least they have gyms to help you burn it off.

Title: "Expect to work like donkey or you will be kicked out"
Main Text: 2. If you work only for 40hours, you won't get promoted and you will be sacked.
Pros: 1. Free food, this is the best part in Google.
Cons: 1. Long working hours, no work-life balance.

Title: "Google was a great place to work, but at the end of the day it was just a job."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 8 years)
Pros: Great pay, amazing benefits, great perks, and stock options.
Cons: No work life balance even though they talk about it a lot. 85% of my team were single, and they worked 70+ hours a week. If you wanted to put out the same amount of work, and meet the expectations of your manager you had to do the same.

Title: "Great company (but employees who needs structure beware)"
Main Text: --Google changes every day which is great from a product perspective but can be frustrating as an employee who wants to have a consistent manager.
Pros: The people at Google are amazing and great to work with. Pay, perks, and benefits are excellent. There is some new challenge to solve each day and the impact that you can have is monumental.
Cons: --Unless you're above a certain level, it can be tough to move internally despite what any recruiter might say to you.

Title: "Amazing, Amazing. Love my work!"
Main Text: Amazing MTV campus facilities and staff, free food, and incredible compensation. I can't think of anywhere else I'd rather work.
Pros: Good work/life balance. I get to work with incredibly talented and driven people— no driftwood! Google is always working on a thousand different things, so there's always opportunities to try something new.
Cons: Because there's always so much going on, many projects get cancelled or re-assigned, which means there can be some shuffling around. However, for me, this resolved with me moving into a much better position on a great team.

Title: "Getting big and hard to get your voice heard"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 8 years)
Pros: Diversity and lots of talented people in there, management style of 7:1 and very each to communicate with manager and director, peers are wonderful and love the 360 peer review system
Cons: Organization gets too big and gets hard to stay in cozy start up environment during 2005 when I first joined. Some managers are getting less qualified as they are from top MBA schools, too much strategy talks but no implementations, too political sometimes!

Title: "nice"
Pros: everything was pretty much great
Cons: pay was not up to industry standards

Title: "Amazing"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Working at Google was refreshing but also shows that your life is suppose to be dedicated to work. They offer almost any amenity that you will possibly need so as to keep you working. All in all that isn't a bad thing but have a balance of work and life is paramount if you don't want to burn out. My position was transitionary so I did not experience the full intensity of the work life, but I was around it and could …
Cons: Google lives to the hype in everything but transparency. The food is excellent and free, its fun, but your managers will not tell you if you need to move or if your not performing well. You can lose your job quickly if you aren't aware of what they think about you.

Title: "Fun, friendly, and fast paced work environment."
Main Text: Ask more behavioral questions during interviews and try not to dwell on trivial knowledge that will rarely be used in the role that is being applied for.
Pros: Great perks and benefits.
Cons: Too many overqualified employees are considered during performance reviews, making promotion difficult.

Title: "Great company with great products."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: Youthful culture. Relative lack of politics
Cons: Lots of smart people means a lot of people are underutilized.

Title: "Google is awesome"
Main Text: Sometimes management have product decisions that even most of Googlers do not approve.
Pros: Challenging everyday work.
Cons: Google is a big company now. It's not a startup and you won't be making $millions (but you will be comfortable).

Title: "An amazing place to work"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Amazing career opportunities and a great place to jumpstart your career. There is a good amount of lateral mobility within the company which is great if you want to make a job change without switching companies.
Cons: As Google is getting bigger it is getting more difficult to have your opinion heard and to move quickly within the organization. Promotions can be hard to come by and take much longer here than at other companies.

Title: "network engineer"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Good company, management lets you do your work, very flexible
Cons: It almost feels like a social club, good for some though

Title: "decent company to work for"
Pros: great team work spirits and communication
Cons: not that effective in innovation

Title: "Best company I've ever worked for."
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Working at a company where amazing things are made, the people are smart and the food is amazing.
Cons: Engineers rule. If you aren't one, you may feel slighted. Also, school snobbery may keep your department from being able to hire talented people, and force you to accept other candidates who are less desirable but went to a top tier schoo.

Title: "Analyst"
Pros: Good company, Good People, Great Place
Cons: Long hours, Long Commute, Lots of programming

Title: "Great Company to work for"
Pros: Free food, everyone is extremely nice and Googlely, bikes everywhere, massage chairs
Cons: Similar problems to every big corporation

Title: "Believe the hype"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Google is really a fantastic place to work. You get to engage with challenging, exciting problems at the height of your intelligence, in a community of passionate, brilliant peers.
Cons: Google is a huge multinational corporation, so -- while they do make an admirable attempt at shielding individual employees from all the bureaucracy and inertia that entails -- those downsides are not entirely avoidable.

Title: "Data Scientist, Big Data Analysis"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: Everything is wonderful here! I'm very satisfied with my job and see a very successful future. The culture is wonderful.
Cons: Sometimes management can be problematic but there is very little I can sat that's negative about Google. People who work here understand it.

Title: "What you've heard is true..."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: As far as big companies go, I'm convinced that Google is the best place to work. You simply cannot beat the quality of your coworkers, the perks, the benefits... Google is a company that truly cares for their employees.
Cons: It *is* a big company now. I happened to start in 2007, when my team was small and scrappy, which was challenging, but super fun at the same time. The company is certainly much bigger now, and that fun, small, scrappy feeling is fading.

Title: "Best IT Company on earth"
Pros: Excellent environment and brilliant engineers. Plenty of free food. Enjoy a lot of perks in Bay area. The gLearn system allow you keep studying after college.
Cons: Not really. It is too large sometimes feel lost.

Title: "Great company"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Lots of smart people, fantastic perks. I learned more here than I have anywhere else in my professional history. The older teams, such as infrastructure and apps have people that can teach you more in an hour than you learn many places in your entire tenure.
Cons: most of the technology is inhouse, and google faces problems no one else does, so what you learn is non-transferable. Offices outside of Mountain View are treated very poorly.

Title: "loved it"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: work environment was very fantastic
Cons: i didnt have any to report

Title: "Great"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Great engineers, teaches best practices. Great perks, very comfortable.
Cons: Hard to acquire breadth of knowledge if you haven't worked for a while. It's hard to learn how to "do things" that apply to outside of Google if you work at Google.

Title: "Wonderful"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: Amazing environment, full of energy and a positive attitude
Cons: Interview was not that difficult, overall experience was great.

Title: "Company is so big, feel like a number...."
Main Text: Office environment is over the top.
Pros: Benefits are unmatched by other employers!
Cons: After being acquired, I went from being recognized for my contributions to being a number. Hated the review process and rating peers. Some peers would rate you and not have any direct contact with you. Didn't seem fair!

Title: "Awesome place to work"
Main Text: Great perks, great salary, great work, great team, great leadership.
Pros: Love the work, I have a great team, I love the companies mission statement and I believe in their leadership.
Cons: I have no complaints.

Title: "Engineering Program Manager"
Main Text: Cool culture
Pros: Amazing place to work
Cons: Too much infusion of Apple culture

Title: "A nice place, but in the South Bay"
Main Text: - Work/life balance was quite terrible
Pros: - Great benefits, reputation
Cons: - Commuting to the South Bay every day

Title: "Love working there"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Great benefits, perks, compensation, work/life balance. Company invests in the very long term.
Cons: Compensation not strongly tied to performance.

Title: "Satisfactory"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: You get to work on exciting and challenging problems.
Cons: It has become really slow moving of late. It takes enormous amount of time for getting an idea implemented, which is kind of frustrating.

Title: "Great place, innovative environment with smart people!"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: You get exposed to so many areas of technology, and through the eyes of a company leading the charge to these spaces. Always at the forefront of what's going on and what's changing the world.
Cons: It's a large company now, sometimes not as nimble as smaller competitors. Also promotion is very challenging.

Title: "Great engineers working on boring code."
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Most people are smart, lots of vacation days, lots of perks, good food, many interesting distractions like guest speakers, nap pods, good culture. Pay is decent, but not as good as elsewhere.
Cons: I'm used to startup culture, and I had a serious culture shock coming to Google. Maybe it varies somewhat by team, but from my vantage point, engineering seemed very bloated and bureaucratic. There is an obscenely long and restrictive "style guide" of programming rules that must be followed and company-wide banned language features that makes coding much less productive than I'm used to. Code reviews sometimes …

Title: "Awesome people. Awesome problems."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (Less than a year)
Pros: Great coworkers, great food, amazing tools. Really the best place for an engineer.
Cons: You have to fight for the good projects. Everyone around you is smart. (This is a good thing though.)

Title: "Overall a great company"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Fooood. More than 20 cafes is simply amazing.
Cons: It's now a huge company.

Title: "Awesome"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: It's a baller place to work.
Cons: There's none i can think of

Title: "Happy Googler - Works a lot"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Great people, treated well with surprises every day
Cons: too much work, never stops. lots of weekends + nights

Title: "Lots of opportunities for groweth"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Great people that will push you and give you opportunities to see things in a new way.
Cons: It's a big company now. It often takes a lot of effort to start new projects and there are plenty of distracting or disassociated programs. It's controlled, fast chaos at times.

Title: "I build things, and it's fun!"
Main Text: + Smart peers, awesome project, if you get lucky or a particular team wants you.
Pros: + Larry wants us to keep the soul of a startup, even though we no longer are one. In some teams, like the ones I've been on, this has been possible - going from an idea to millions of users on a new product in < 2 years. Twice.
Cons: + Not-as-smart peers if you are not lucky, and possibly less-exciting projects, too. In this case you need to pay your dues on that project for 12-18 months, before being able to transfer.

Title: "Great company to get you spoiled on perks but culture is getting very corporate."
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 8 years)
Pros: High salary. Many perks. Great breakfast and lunch. Working with some very smart people. Learning all the Google technology. Free phone or tablet once a year. If you worked on a cool product and post on social media, you would probably have many followers. Company encourages employees to move around within the company. Free shuttle service to work.
Cons: Working with some very smart people can also turn into a bad thing because some smart people are real a** hole sometimes. Company is getting big and corporate. 20% project is available only when 100% is done. Performance review is still a mystery to me. I had gotten bad rating for working my butt off and good rating for not doing much.

Title: "Google CSSI"
Main Text: I have been working at Google part-time (Less than a year)
Pros: It was a nice working environment
Cons: There wasn't any cons for Google!

Title: "A great company"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: You can change the world while working in Google
Cons: Company gets bigger, more internal competition

Title: "Good"
Pros: Good food, good salary, good people.
Cons: too many people around the world.

Title: "Amazing place to work"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: An innovative company with many things to do. You can get massages and many other things to keep an employ busy.
Cons: They have high expectations, and there is a lot of work. There is nothing else wrong about it besides what I have previously said.

Title: "the very best"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)

Cons: processes tend to be heavy sometimes

Title: "Google Review"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 8 years)
Pros: Google is an awesome place to work with many great perks available to all employees
Cons: The Con I generally have personally is that I have more awesome ideas than I have spare cycles to work on. There just isn't enough time in the day :)

Title: "perfect company"

Title: "The best company I've worked for, by a mile"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Great culture, awesome products, wall-to-wall smart people.
Cons: Hyperactive organisation can be exhausting.

Title: "The best company that I ever worked for."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Great and fun place to work. Still start-up atmosphere, but stable and strong business foundation. Happy to work with talented colleagues. Good foods!
Cons: Watch out your weight! You can gain your weight very easily due to too good food.

Title: "Great company to work for"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: Freedom to work on projects that really interest you.
Cons: As Google grows, it is becoming a little more bureaucratic and harder to just do cool stuff.

Title: "Test Engineer"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Excellent compensation, benefits, and work environment.
Cons: Could handle employee acquisitions better.

Title: "Great place to work, with smart people"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Awesome challenges, great environment, great benefits
Cons: Odd people at times (too nerdy/awkward).

Title: "Fantastic career starter!"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: people, free food, thought leadership, impactful / world changing work, great learning bed
Cons: company has gotten too big for a ton of growth opportunities, hard to leave bc spoiled by the benefits

Title: "Great place, if you fit the mold."
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: The benefits are great, the culture is great, and the technical challenges can only be found at a handful of places on earth.
Cons: There's a very deep org tree, and half of the people between you and the top are not managers first. There's also an annoying culture of entitlement, especially among some of the people who were recruited straight out of college and take the perks for granted, but it's easy to avoid.

Title: "Wonderful Company"
Main Text: - Parallel growth opportunities
Pros: - Comfortable environment

Title: "There is a Dark Side"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Everyone knows about the great perks and salaries are good.
Cons: As a long time Googler (more than 10 years), it pains me to write this, but it has gotten so bad that I feel compelled. Google used to be a place driven by a culture of collaboration, innovation, and, well, Googleyness. Unfortunately, this is no longer the case. The culture has descended into one where employees are pitted against each other by a rating system that forces managers to choose their best team members, …

Title: "Senior Software Engineer"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Great benefits and compensation. Open culture. Interesting projects.
Cons: Some managers are not entirely competent. Expectation is very high. Limited growth opportunities.

Title: "Great Company, Lots of Opportunity"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Lots of resources, great managers
Cons: Big, hard to get things done.

Title: "Working at Google was awesome"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: The best reason to work at Google is to experience the pinnacle of tech companies. The culture there shows that they value their employees. From the free lunches, to recreational spaces, in depth training and a beautiful campus, it was a great experience during my time there working on a contract project.
Cons: One of the downsides during my employment at Google was the temporary nature of the project I was working on. I only wish that there was an opportunity for a permanent position on the project.

Title: "Staff quality engineer"
Pros: Work environment is great here than

Title: "Amazing"

Title: "Operations Manager"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Challenging projects. Autonomy. Fast moving in small teams

Title: "Good perks & benefits"
Main Text: And yeah work life balance is non existent.
Pros: Needless to say - great perks - food, facilities, gym, shuttles, medical benefits etc. Decent compensation. Good brand on your resume
Cons: I doubt if the hiring bar is the same outside of engineering - specifically staffing. Most of the leadership have no idea about managing teams. For all the talk of Google being a metrics driven company...staffing seems ridiculously off - they talk in terms of numbers yes but most of the time the leadership barely even knows what targets staffing is chasing. Seniority is rarely rewarded and rather than giving …

Title: "Awesome"
Pros: Everyone knows about the perks and unconventional culture.
Cons: No comment on this topic.

Title: "They care about their people"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: Insanely smart people everywhere (not just eng/prod). Looking for game changing ways to approach every problem. The food and shuttles are great benefits. You can end up working a lot but it's generally because you want to, not because you have to.
Cons: Has lost the start-up culture. It's big, it's political and it's expected. It's a gigantic company and compared to overall revenues and growth the company has managed to stay as "un political" as possible.

Title: "Offers smart teammates, great compensation, and tons of perks"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 3 years)
Pros: Managers that are invested in your growth/professional development.
Cons: Sometimes it can be hard to get things done due to too many cooks in the kitchen

Title: "Large company, brilliant colleagues, amazing perks."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: You work with some of the best and brightest in the world. Whichever field you're in there'll be at least one and probably several of the field's most renown luminaries working at Google. The perks are amazing, it's a great environment to get things done.
Cons: Google is a giant company with more structure and inertia than I expected. There is a lot of duplication of effort and it is really difficult to have a company wide impact.

Title: "Working with great people on exciting products, very satisfied."
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than 5 years)
Pros: Casual but fast-paced work environment, mobility, concern for work-life balance.
Cons: Many technologies are Google-specific, would not necessarily translate well to another employer.

Title: "Google was an amazing place to work at"
Pros: Google offers an environment that allows you to focus on your work. They take care of your three meals if need be, offer classes of all sorts, provide you with the space to rest, and etc. Even if your work is demanding, it is very easy to relax and take a break.
Cons: I would have liked more opportunities to meet different people. In general I think it is a quiet office where people work a lot.

Title: "Perks are cool, but co-workers are better"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time (More than a year)
Pros: Best and brightest engineers I've ever worked with, very forgiving atmosphere, easy to change teams if something interesting comes along, lots of opportunity to visit offices in other cities and countries.
Cons: Self-induced pressure to "keep up" with the best of the engineers, a few "difficult" personalities.

Title: "Great working environment"
Pros: Friendly people and excellent working environment
Cons: Every thing is good enough

Title: "Good overall environment, but dealing with HR is annoying"
Main Text: Approves of CEO
Pros: Great people, cool work, fun environment
Cons: HR is not as transparent as they say and switching between roles and getting promoted is not as easy as they claim.

Title: "Great Perks"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: Awesome place to work if you are a software engineer, are under 30 and thrive in an intense metric-based environment. Lots of smart people, lots of incredible perks.
Cons: Engineering is king so if you are working in some of the other departments, like HR/staffing, you may not feel as "special". The conversion process to go from contractor to FTE is flawed and they string you out to the end of your contract. Ideal candidates are 2-3 years out of a top-tier university; staffing experience not required. Experienced recruiters and sourcers are better off going elsewhere as Google doesn't …

Title: "A great place to spend ~2 years"
Main Text: Show More
Pros: One of the best places to learn exceptional client services. Typically very fun teams and co-workers. There are some exceptional leaders in the company to emulate and learn from. Free, healthy food, gym re-imbursement, massage etc are all great to have
Cons: The company has gotten to a size that it is very large. Lots of internal politics and incredibly difficult to elevate your career. Because of the size of the company, the process of quarterly evaluations and performance scores is incredibly competitive, cut throat and sadly...now fosters an environment of team mates meanly pitting themselves against each other. It's incredibly sad to see. You can bust your chops for …

Title: "Decent place for a contract employee"
Main Text: I have been working at Google full-time
Pros: The environment for short-term contract employees was far more respectful, dynamic, and downright fun than any other I've experienced.
Cons: Short-term contracts inevitably mean high turnover and high loss of tribal knowledge, although this was mitigated to some degree by reasonable training and team structure.

Title: "software engineer"

Title: "Great place to work at"

Title: "web search engineer"

Title: "Good, but if you are remote, you don't fit in"
Main Text: I worked at Google full-time (More than a year)
